title: 이/가 [i/ga] (Subject markers)
short_explanation: These are subject markers used to identify and emphasize the subject in a sentence.
long_explanation: '이/가 [i/ga]' are postpositions used in Korean to mark the subject of a sentence. They are attached right after a noun to indicate that the noun is the subject of the sentence. The choice between '이' and '가' depends on whether the noun ends in a vowel or a consonant. If the noun ends with a consonant, '이' is used. If the noun ends with a vowel, '가' is used.
formation: Noun + 이/가 + rest of the sentence

examples.kr: 나는 사과를 먹어요, 근데 친구는 오렌지가 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun sagwareul meogeoyo, geunde chinguneun orenjiga joayo.
examples.en: I eat apples, but my friend likes oranges.

examples.kr: 저의 강아지가 소파 위에 뛰어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoi gangajiga sopa wie ttwieoyo.
examples.en: My dog jumps on the sofa.

examples.kr: 이 책이 제일 재미있어요.
examples.romaji: I chaekeun jeil jaemiisseoyo.
examples.en: This book is the most fun.

examples.kr: 당신이 좋아하는 음식이 뭔가요?
examples.romaji: Dangsini joahaneun eumsigi mwongayo?
examples.en: What is the food that you like?

title: 은/는 [eun/neun] (Topic markers)
short_explanation: Used to mark the topic of a sentence or to contrast an idea or subject.
long_explanation: '은/는 [eun/neun]' are particle markers in Korean used to introduce or highlight the topic of a sentence. They follow a noun to indicate what the speaker is talking about, drawing attention to it. '은 [eun]' is used after words ending with a consonant, and '는 [neun]' is used after words ending with a vowel. These markers can also be used to contrast an idea, person, or thing with another.

examples.kr: 나는 학생입니다. 나는 한국어를 배우고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun haksaengimnida. Naneun hangugeoreul baeugo itsseumnida.
examples.en: I am a student. I am learning Korean.

examples.kr: 친구는 집에 있고, 저는 학교에 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Chinguneun jibe itgo, jeoneun hakgyoe itsseumnida.
examples.en: My friend is at home, and I am at school.

examples.kr: 오늘은 비가 오고, 내일은 맑습니다.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun biga ogo, naeireun malgsseumnida.
examples.en: It's raining today, but it will be clear tomorrow.

examples.kr: 이것은 책이고, 저것은 연필입니다.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun chaegigo, jeogeoseun yeonpilimnida.
examples.en: This is a book, and that is a pencil.

title: 을/를 [eul/reul] (Object markers)
short_explanation: Used to mark the object of a sentence in Korean.
long_explanation: '을/를 [eul/reul]' are object markers in Korean, indicating the object of an action in a sentence. They are the equivalents of 'it' or 'them' in English. They are used after a noun which is the object of the verb. They have no meaning on their own, but when attached to a noun, they signify that the noun is the object that the action of the verb is directed at.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침에 커피를 마셔요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achime keopireul masyeoyo.
examples.en: I drink coffee every morning.

examples.kr: 저는 이 책을 읽고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun i chaekeul ilgo isseoyo.
examples.en: I am reading this book.

examples.kr: 영화를 보러 가고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Yeongwareul boreo gago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to go watch a movie.

examples.kr: 우리는 그들을 돕고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun geudeureul dobgo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: We want to help them.

title: 아니다 [anida] (To not be)
short_explanation: Used to express negation; 'to not be' or 'is not'.
long_explanation: '아니다 [anida]' is a negative verb used in Korean to indicate the non-existence or negation of something. It stands as the negative form of the verb 'to be.' '아니다' is used when the speaker wants to say a statement is incorrect or a certain condition or state is not present. This verb is not always used in its base form, it can change form to agree with formalities and tenses.

examples.kr: 제 책이 아니에요, 그것은 내 친구의 책입니다.
examples.romaji: Je chaeki anieyo, geugeoseun nae chinguui chaegimnida.
examples.en: That's not my book, it's my friend's book.

examples.kr: 우리는 너무 늦지 않았어요, 아직도 충분한 시간이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun neomu neutji anasseoyo, ajikdo chungbunhan sigani isseoyo.
examples.en: We are not too late, we still have plenty of time.

examples.kr: 이 아름다운 공원은 자연이 아니에요, 인간이 만든 것입니다.
examples.romaji: I areumdaun gongwoneun jayeoni anieyo, ingani mandeun geosimnida.
examples.en: This beautiful park is not natural, it was made by humans.

examples.kr: 그는 나의 친구가 아니에요, 우리는 그저 동료입니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun naui chinguga anieyo, urineun geujeo donglyoimnida.
examples.en: He is not my friend, we are just colleagues.

title: 예요/이에요 [yeyo/ieyo] (Descriptive verb ending in present tense)
short_explanation: Used to attach to a descriptive verb stem in present tense.
long_explanation: '예요/이에요 [yeyo/ieyo]' are polite ending forms used in Korean to complete descriptive verb stems in the present tense. These forms are used to declare facts, express personal feelings or opinions, and are often used in conversations to describe something or someone. The difference between the two forms is based on the final syllable of the word they are attached to: use '이에요' for words ending in a consonant and '예요' for words ending in a vowel.
formation: Descriptive Verb Stem + 예요 (if stem ends with a vowel) / 이에요 (if stem ends with a consonant)

examples.kr: 나는 학생이에요, 서울에서 대학교에 다니고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun haksaeng-ieyo, seoul-eseo daehakgyo-e danigo isseoyo.
examples.en: I am a student, studying at a university in Seoul.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨는 정말 좋아요, 하늘도 푸르고 해도 빛나고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssineun jeongmal joayeo, haneuldo pureugo haedo bitnago isseoyo.
examples.en: The weather today is really good, the sky is blue and the sun is shining.

examples.kr: 이 꽃은 예뻐요, 꽃잎이 핑크색이고 향기도 좋아요.
examples.romaji: I kkoch-eun yeppeoyo, kkoch-ip-i pingkusaeg-igo hyanggi-do joayo.
examples.en: This flower is pretty, its petals are pink and it smells good.

examples.kr: 우리 강아지는 귀여워요, 작은 꼬리를 흔들며 항상 저를 환영해요.
examples.romaji: Uri gangajineun gwiyeowoyo, jageun kkolileul heundeulmyeo hangsang jeoleul hwan-yeonghaeyo.
examples.en: Our puppy is cute, always welcoming me by wagging its little tail.

title: 아요/어요/여요 [ayo/eoyo/yeoyo] (Verb ending in present tense)
short_explanation: Used as a polite verb ending in present tense.
long_explanation: '아요/어요/여요 [ayo/eoyo/yeoyo]' are endings attached to Korean verbs or adjectives in order to make sentences in present tense. They are often used in casual, polite speeches. The ending used depends on the final vowel of the stem: if the stem ends in '아' or '오', use '아요'; for any other vowel, '어요' is used. If the stem ends with '하다', use '여요'.
formation: Verb/adjective stem + 아요 (if stem ends in '아' or '오') / 어요 (all other vowels) / 여요 (if stem ends with '하다')

examples.kr: 나는 한국어 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangugeo gongbuhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I am studying Korean.

examples.kr: 우리 엄마는 맛있는 음식을 만들어요.
examples.romaji: Uri eommaneun masitneun eumsigeul mandeureoyo.
examples.en: My mom makes delicious food.

examples.kr: 선생님은 학생들에게 한국 문화에 대해 가르치고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimeun haksaengdeulege hanguk munhwa-e daehae gareuchigo isseoyo.
examples.en: The teacher is teaching the students about Korean culture.

examples.kr: 그는 점심시간에 가끔 산책하러 가요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jeomsimsigan-e gakkeum sancaekhaleo gayo.
examples.en: He sometimes goes for a walk during lunchtime.

title: 고 [go] (And)
short_explanation: This is used to link two or more clauses in a sentence; 'and'.
long_explanation: '고 [go]' is a conjunction used in Korean to connect two or more clauses in a sentence. It is similar to the English conjunction 'and'. It can be used to link actions, events, and states in the same context. Do note that all verbs and adjectives before '고' should be in their dictionary or base forms, which makes it easy to use.

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 학교에 가고, 공부하고, 친구들과 점심을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul hakgyoe gago, gongbuhago, chingudeulgwa jeomsimeul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: Today, I went to school, studied, and ate lunch with my friends.

examples.kr: 그는 춤을 추고, 노래를 하고, 재미있게 놀았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chumeul chugo, noraereul hago, jaemiissge norasseoyo.
examples.en: He danced, sang, and had fun.

examples.kr: 나는 집에 가서 숙제를 하고 책을 읽었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jibe gaseo sukjerul hago chaegeul ilgeosseoyo.
examples.en: I went home, did my homework, and read a book.

examples.kr: 우리는 점심을 먹고 영화를 보러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jeomsimeul meokgo yeonghwareul boreo gasseoyo.
examples.en: We ate lunch and went to watch a movie.

title: 하고 [hago] (And, with)
short_explanation: Used to express 'and' or 'with' in terms of connecting nouns or sharing activities.
long_explanation: '하고 [hago]' is a conjunction used in Korean to link or associate two or more nouns or to express doing something together with someone. It conveys a sense of conjunction similar to 'and' in English where two or more things or people are combined or linked. Also, it is used to denote the concept of 'with' when expressing doing something in a company or joint activity with others.

examples.kr: 저는 친구하고 영화를 보고 밥을 먹었어요, 그리고 집에 가서 숙제를 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chinguhago yeongwareul bogo babeul meogeosseoyo, geurigo jibe gaseo sukje eul hayeossseoyo.
examples.en: I watched a movie and ate with my friend, then went home and did my homework.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에는 가족하고 여행을 가기로 결정했어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumaleneun gajokhago yeohaengeul gagi ro gyeoljeonghaessseoyo.
examples.en: I decided to go on a trip with my family this weekend.

examples.kr: 피터하고 메리는 함께 학교에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Piteohago Merineun hamkke hakgyoe gasseoyo.
examples.en: Peter and Mary went to school together.

examples.kr: 나는 오늘 아빠하고 쇼핑하러 갈 계획이에요.
examples.romaji: Naneun oneul appahago syopingharero gal gyehoegieyo.
examples.en: I plan to go shopping with my dad today.

title: (으)세요 [(eu)seyo] (Imperative form)
short_explanation: Used to give orders, instructions or make requests in a polite manner.
long_explanation: '(으)세요 [(eu)seyo]' is an imperative grammatical point used in Korean to instruct, give orders or make polite requests. It's used in sentences where you want someone to do something. This form is an honorific, thus it's used in a formal setting or when speaking to someone who is older or of a higher status. Verbs with a final vowel in the stem take '세요' while verbs with a final consonant in the stem take '으세요'.
formation: Verb-stem + 세요 if the verb stem's final syllable is a vowel, Verb-stem + 으세요 if the verb stem's final syllable is a consonant

examples.kr: 조심해서 건너세요, 사고가 날 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Josimhaeseo geonneoseyo, sagoga nal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Cross carefully, there could be an accident.

examples.kr: 집에 돌아가서 먹어야 할 약을 먹으세요.
examples.romaji: Jibe doragaseo meog-eoya hal yag-eul meog-euseyo.
examples.en: Go home and take the medicine you should take.

examples.kr: 이 메시지를 받으면 답장하세요.
examples.romaji: I mesijireul badeumyeon dapjanghaseyo.
examples.en: Reply once you receive this message.

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁에 만나야 할 사람들에게 미리 전화하세요.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeog-e manna-ya hal salam-deul-egge miri jeonhwahaseyo.
examples.en: Call the people you have to meet this evening in advance.

title: (으)ㄹ 수 있다 [(eu)l su itda] (Can do)
short_explanation: This form indicates the potential ability or possibility to perform something.
long_explanation: '(으)ㄹ 수 있다 [(eu)l su itda]' is a fundamental Korean grammar point that conveys the potential ability to do something. It is an auxiliary verb expressing that an action is possible given the circumstances, or indicates the potential that an event may occur. This also implies the speaker has the ability to perform, or is allowed to do, the action described by the preceding verb.
formation: (Verb Stem) + ㄹ 수 있다 OR (Verb Stem ending with a vowel) + ㄹ 수 있다, (Verb Stem ending with 'ㄹ') + 수 있다

examples.kr: 그녀는 한국어를 매우 빠르게 배울 수 있으므로, 한 달 만에 토픽 시험을 볼 수 있을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hangungeoreul maeu bbareuge baeul su isseumyeo, han dal mane topik siheomeul bol su isseul geosibnida.
examples.en: She has the ability to learn Korean very quickly, so she will be able to take the TOPIK test in a month.

examples.kr: 집이 가까우니까, 열심히 공부하면 한 달 안에 한국어를 유창하게 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jibi gakkaunikka, yeolsimhi gongbuhamyoen han dal ane hangungeoreul yuchanghage hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: As the house is near, if you study hard, you can become fluent in Korean within a month.

examples.kr: 그것에 대해 많이 알고 있어서, 그에 대한 모든 질문에 답할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geugeosae daehae manhi algo isseoseo, geue daehan modeun jilmune daphal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Since I know a lot about it, I can answer all questions about it.

examples.kr: 당신이 이해하기 어렵다면, 조금 더 천천히 말할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini ihaehagi eoryeopdamyeon, jogeum deo cheoncheonhi malhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: If you find it hard to understand, I can speak a little slower.

title: (으)려고 [(eu)ryeogo] (Intention to do)
short_explanation: Used to express the speaker's intention or plan to do something.
long_explanation: The '(으)려고 [(eu)ryeogo]' form is used in Korean to express the intention or plan to do something. It is similar to 'intend to', 'plan to', or 'in order to' in English. You can use it for things that you yourself intend to do, as well as other people's intentions you're aware of. This can include future plans, aspirations, or strategies.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우려고 한국에 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul baeuryeogo hanguge watseoyo.
examples.en: I came to Korea to learn Korean.

examples.kr: 누나는 살을 빼려고 운동하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Nuna-neun sal-eul ppael yuh-go oon-dong-ha-go iss-uh-yo.
examples.en: My older sister is exercising in order to lose weight.

examples.kr: 학생들은 시험에 통과하려고 열심히 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Haksaeng-deul-eun siheom-e tonggwahal leou-go yeolsimhi gongbuha-go iss-eo-yo.
examples.en: The students are studying hard in order to pass the exam.

examples.kr: 아빠는 아이들에게 좋은 생활을 제공하려고 매일 일해요.
examples.romaji: Appa-neun a-ideul-eh-ge jo-eun saeng-hwal-eul jegongha-leou-go mae-il il-hae-yo.
examples.en: Father works every day in order to provide a good life for the children.

title: (으)ㄴ/는다 [(eu)n/neunda] (Informal statement endings)
short_explanation: Used in informal and casual conversations to make assertions, statements or give descriptions.
long_explanation: '(으)ㄴ/는다 [(eu)n/neunda]' are informal statement endings in Korean. They are commonly used in casual conversations among friends or peers to make assertions, express opinions, or give descriptions. Regarding its formation, if the stem of the verb ends with a consonant, '는다' is used. Conversely, if the stem of the verb ends with a vowel, 'ㄴ다' is used.
formation: Verb stem ends with a vowel + ㄴ다 / Verb stem ends with a consonant + 는다

examples.kr: 나는 오늘 자정에 집에 돌아온다.
examples.romaji: Naneun oneul jajeonge jibe dorawoonda.
examples.en: I will return home at midnight today.

examples.kr: 그는 스페인어를 잘 한다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun seupeinneoreul jal handa.
examples.en: He speaks Spanish well.

examples.kr: 이 커피는 너무 진하다.
examples.romaji: I keopineun neomu jinhada.
examples.en: This coffee is too strong.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 공원에 가서 피크닉을 한다.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil gongwone gaseo pikeunikeul handa.
examples.en: We're having a picnic in the park tomorrow.

title: 도 [do] (Too, also)
short_explanation: Used to indicate addition, similarity, or emphasis; 'too', 'also', 'even'.
long_explanation: '도 [do]' is a particle used in Korean to express the idea of 'too' or 'also' in a sentence. When attached after a noun, it means that the action applies to that noun as well. It can be used in both positive and negative statements, and can also be used to provide emphasis, often translated as 'even' in English. In other words, 너도 means 'you too', 나도 means 'I also', and 저도 means 'I too'.

examples.kr: 나는 커피를 좋아하고, 친구도 커피를 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun keopireul joahago, chingudo keopireul joahaeyo.
examples.en: I like coffee, and my friend also likes coffee.

examples.kr: 철수는 축구를 할 수 있어요, 그리고 민희도 축구를 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Cheolsuneun chukgureul hal su isseoyo, geurigo Min-heedo chukgureul hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Cheolsu can play soccer, and Minhee can also play soccer.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 재미있어요, 그래서 많은 사람들이 지금까지도 계속 이 영화를 봐요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun jaemiisseoyo, geuraeseo maneun saramdeuli jigeumkkajido gyesok i yeonghwareul bwayo.
examples.en: This movie is fun, so many people still continue to watch this movie.

examples.kr: 이번 시험은 어려웠어요, 그래서 나도, 친구들도 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeun eoryeosseoyo, geuraeseo nado, chingudeuldo mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: This test was difficult, so both I and my friends couldn't do it.

title: 만 [man] (Only)
short_explanation: '만 [man]' is used to express the concept of 'only' or 'just' in Korean.
long_explanation: '만 [man]' is a post-positional particle in Korean language that specifies exclusivity, indicating that the preceding object or person is the 'only' one in the context. The noun before '만' is the only thing or person involved in the action, underlining a sense of limitation. The usage of this particle effectively highlights the exclusivity of the subject in the proceeding action or context.

examples.kr: 저는 커피만 마십니다, 차는 마시지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopiman masimnida, chaneun masiji anhayo.
examples.en: I only drink coffee, I don’t drink tea.

examples.kr: 제 친구는 한국어만 할 줄 알아요, 다른 언어는 할 줄 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Je chinguneun hangugeoman hal jul arayo, dareun eoneoneun hal jul moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: My friend only knows how to speak Korean, I don't think he can speak any other languages.

examples.kr: 저는 데이트를 할 때 영화만 보러 가요, 다른 활동은 잘 안 하게 돼요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun deiteureul hal ttae yeonghwaman boreo gayo, dareun hwaldongeun jal an hage dwaeyo.
examples.en: When I go on dates, I only go to movies, I don't really do any other activities.

examples.kr: 이번 달에는 돈을 아끼려고 나는 교통비만 썼어요, 다른 것들에는 돈을 안 썼어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon dareuneneun doneul akkiryeogo naneun gyotongbiman sseosseoyo, dareun geosdeureneun doneul an sseosseoyo.
examples.en: This month, to save money, I only spent on transportation, I didn't spend on other things.

title: 와/과 [wa/gwa] (And, with – for nouns)
short_explanation: This is used to indicate conjunction between two nouns. It works similar to 'and' or 'with' in English.
long_explanation: '와/과 [wa/gwa]' is a connecting particle used commonly in Korean language to link two nouns and show a relationship between them. This grammar point can be interchangeable depending on the last syllable of the noun. If the last letter of the noun is a vowel, the particle '와' is used, while '과' is attached to a noun ending in a consonant.
formation:
Noun(1st syllable contains vowel) + 와 + Noun 
 Noun(1st syllable contains consonant) + 과 + Noun

examples.kr: 나는 공원에서 강아지와 뛰어 놀았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun gong-won-eseo gang-aji-wa ttui-eo norat-seo-yo.
examples.en: I played with a puppy in the park.

examples.kr: 아침보다 커피랑 빵과 함께 잘 먹어요.
examples.romaji: A-chim-boda ko-pi-rang ppang-gwa ham-kke jal meog-eoyo.
examples.en: I eat well with coffee and bread rather than breakfast.

examples.kr: 친구와 연필과 함께 공부하였어요.
examples.romaji: Chin-gu-wa yeonpil-gwa hamkke gongbuhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I studied with a friend and a pencil.

examples.kr: 나는 내 가족과 함께 여행 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun nae gajok-gwa hamkke yeohaeng gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went on a trip with my family.

title: 부터 [buteo] (From)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the starting point of an action or a range; 'from'.
long_explanation: '부터 [buteo]' is a postposition used in Korean to denote the starting point of an action or to indicate the contiguous order of multiple items in a series. It translates to 'from' in English and is generally used to specify the beginning of a time period, series, or range. It plays a crucial role in constructing temporal or spacial sequences and expressing starting points in the Korean language.

examples.kr: 나는 오늘부터 다이어트를 시작할 거예요, 그래서 단것들은 더 이상 먹지 않을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Naneun oneulbuteo daieoteureul shijakhal geoyeyo, geuraeseo danggeomdeureun deo isang meokji anheul geoyeyo.
examples.en: I will start a diet from today, so I won't eat desserts anymore.

examples.kr: 어린이부터 어른까지 모두 이 영화를 즐길 수 있어요, 많은 메세지와 교훈이 담겨있어요.
examples.romaji: Eorinibuteo eoreunkkaji modu i yeongawareul jeulgil su isseoyo, manheun mesaejirag gyohuni damgyeoisseoyo.
examples.en: Everyone, from children to adults, can enjoy this movie as it contains many messages and lessons.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일부터 다시 일을 시작해야 해요, 그러니 오늘을 체력을 보충하는 데 쓰세요.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeilbuteo dashi ireul shijakhaya haeyo, geureoni oneureul cheolyeogeul bochunghaneun dae sseoseyo.
examples.en: We have to start working again from tomorrow, so use today to replenish your energy.

examples.kr: 나는 작년 여름부터 한국어를 공부하기 시작했어요, 그래서 이제 조금은 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jaknyeon yeoreumbuteo hangugeo gongbuhagi shijakhaesseoyo, geuraeseo ije jogeumeun hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I started studying Korean from last summer, so I can do a little bit now.

title: 까지 [kkaji] (Until, up to)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the endpoint of a range or limit in time, space, amount, or degree.
long_explanation: '까지 [kkaji]' is a postposition used in Korean to limn a limitation or the endpoint of a range. It can be used in various aspects such as time, space, quantity, degree, and more. This is similar to the English concept of 'up to' or 'until'. When used in a sentence, it often designates a certain limit or endpoint.

examples.kr: 첫 번째 학기는 총 여섯 개월 동안이에요. 즉, 1월부터 6월까지입니다.
examples.romaji: Cheot beonjjae hakgineun chong yeoseot gaeweol dongan-ieyo. Jik, 1weolbuteo 6weolkkajiibnida.
examples.en: The first semester is a total of six months. That is, from January until June.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침 일찍 일어나서 밤 10시까지 일합니다.
examples.romaji: jeoneun maeil achim iljjik ileonaseo bam 10sikkaji ilhabnida.
examples.en: I wake up early every morning and work until 10 at night.

examples.kr: 오늘은 돈이 5000원까지 밖에 없어서 저녁을 거르고야 말았어요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun doni 5000wonkkaji bakke eopseoseo jeonyeogeul georeugoya marasseoyo.
examples.en: I only had up to 5000 won today, so I ended up skipping dinner.

examples.kr: 지금까지 한 일을 포함해서 모든 내용을 보고서에 적어주세요.
examples.romaji: jigeumkkaji han ireul pohamhaeseo modeun naeyong-eul bogoseoe jeog-eojuseyo.
examples.en: Please write down everything, including what you've done up until now, in the report.

title: 아/어/여서 [a/eo/yeoseo] (Because, since)
short_explanation: Used to denote a reason or cause, the equivalent of 'because' or 'since' in English.
long_explanation: '아/어/여서 [a/eo/yeoseo]' is a conjunction used in the Korean language to indicate a cause or reason. It indicates the reason why something occurred, similar to 'because' or 'since' in English. It comes after a verb and signifies that the clause preceding it is the reason or cause of the clause following it.

examples.kr: 밖에 비가 오는데 저는 감기에 걸렸어요, 그래서 학교에 가지 못하고 집에 머물렀어요.
examples.romaji: Bakke biga oneunde jeoneun gamgie geollyeosseo, geuraeseo hakgyoe gaji mothago jibe meomulleosseo.
examples.en: It was raining outside and I caught a cold, so I couldn't go to school and stayed at home.

examples.kr: 그는 배가 고프다고 해서, 저는 간식을 준비했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun baega gopeudago haeseo, jeoneun gansigeul junbihaesseoyo.
examples.en: Since he said he was hungry, I prepared a snack.

examples.kr: 영화를 보느라고 시간이 없어서, 숙제를 전혀 할 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwareul boneurago sigani eopseoseo, sugjereul jeonhyeo hal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: Because I was watching a movie, and didn't have time, I couldn't do any homework.

examples.kr: 수업이 어렵다고 생각해서, 매일 열심히 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sueobi eoryeodago saenggakhaeseo, maeil yeolsimhi gongbu hago isseoyo.
examples.en: Because I think the class is hard, I am studying hard every day.

title: (으)면 [(eu)myeon] (If, when)
short_explanation: This is generally used to express 'if' or 'when'. It's employed to present any conditions and a consequence that can occur due to such conditions.
long_explanation: (으)면 [(eu)myeon] is a conditional ending in Korean that is attached to the stem of a verb or adjective to express meanings such as 'if', 'when', or 'in case'. This grammar point is used to create sentences that contain a situation (condition) and a resulting action (consequence). The condition is expressed in the clause with (으)면, and the consequence or result is expressed in the main clause that follows.

examples.kr: 시간이 있으면, 저는 매일 한국어를 공부하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Sigani isseumyeon, jeoneun maeil hangugeoreul gongbuhago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: If I have time, I want to study Korean every day.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋으면 나는 산에 등산하러 갈 것이야.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga joheumyeon naneun sane deungsanhareo gal geosiya.
examples.en: If the weather is good, I will go hiking in the mountains.

examples.kr: 피곤하면 일찍 자는 것이 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Pigonhamyeon iljjik janeun geosi joayo.
examples.en: If you are tired, it is good to sleep early.

examples.kr: 이 테스트를 통과하면, 나는 학교에 입학할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: I teseuteureul tong-gwahamyeon, naneun hakgyoe ibhakhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: If I pass this test, I can enter school.

title: 너무 [neomu] (Too, very)
short_explanation: Used to express a high degree or extent; 'too', 'very'.
long_explanation: '너무 [neomu]' is an adverb used in Korean to express a strong emphasis on the degree or extent of an action or state, such as 'too much' or 'very' in English. It is used to heighten the intensity or urgency of the verb or adjective it modifies and is often used to convey an excess or extreme condition.

examples.kr: 이것은 너무 맛있어서 제가 모두 먹어버렸어요, 다른 사람들을 위해 남겨두지 못했습니다.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun neomu masisseoseo jega modu meogeobeoryeosseoyo, dareun saramdeureul wihae namgyeoduji moshaessseubnida.
examples.en: This was so delicious that I ate it all, I couldn't leave any for others.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 너무 재미있어서 저는 이미 세 번이나 봤어요, 아직도 다시 보고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun neomu jaemiisseoseo jeoneun imi se beon-ina bwass-eoyo, ajikdo dasi bogo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: This movie is so interesting that I've already watched it three times, and I still want to watch it again.

examples.kr: 그녀가 너무 예뻐서 저는 매일 그녀를 볼 수 있으면 좋겠어요, 하지만 그녀는 저를 몰라요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga neomu yeppeoseo jeoneun maeil geunyeoreul bol su isseumyeon johgess-eoyo, hajiman geunyeoneun jeoleul mollayo.
examples.en: She is so pretty that I wish I could see her every day, but she doesn't know me.

examples.kr: 피자가 너무 맛있어서 저는 매주 먹어요, 하지만 이제부터는 조금 줄여야 될 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Pijaga neomu masisseoseo jeoneun maeju meogeoyo, hajiman ijebuteoneun jogeum julyeoya doel geot gatayo.
examples.en: The pizza is so delicious that I eat it every week, but I think I should cut down a bit from now on.

title: 많이 [manhi] (A lot)
short_explanation: Used to express a large quantity, frequency or degree; 'a lot', 'many', 'much'.
long_explanation: '많이 [manhi]' is an adverb used in Korean to indicate a large quantity or degree, or a high frequency of an action. It is similar to 'a lot', 'many', or 'much' in English. It can be used with both countable and uncountable nouns and verbs to describe a large amount, a high frequency, or a significant degree of something.

examples.kr: 저는 친구가 많이 필요해서 항상 사람들을 만나러 다니는 편이에요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chinguga manhi piryohae-seo hangsang saramdeu-reul mannareo danineun pyeon-ieyo.
examples.en: I need a lot of friends, so I tend to go out to meet people.

examples.kr: 그 영화를 봤어요? 저는 많이 웃었어요!
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwa-reul bwass-eoyo? Jeoneun manhi useoss-eoyo!
examples.en: Have you seen that movie? I laughed a lot!

examples.kr: 요즘 일이 많이 바빠서 휴가를 가고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum ili manhi bappaseo hyuga-reul gago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I've been very busy at work these days, so I want to go on vacation.

examples.kr: 그녀는 항상 많이 운동해서 건강해 보이세요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hangsang manhi undong-haeseo geonganghae boijyo.
examples.en: She always exercises a lot, so she seems healthy.

title: 조금 [jogeum] (A little)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a small amount or degree; 'a little', 'a bit'.
long_explanation: '조금 [jogeum]' is a commonly used adverb in Korean language that indicates a small amount, quantity, or degree of something. It is equivalent to 'a little' or 'a bit' in English. It can be used with both action verbs and descriptive verbs to talk about lessening the intensity or nature of an action, state or characteristic. This word adds a nuance of reduction, moderation, or restraint.

examples.kr: 기분이 안 좋아요, 조금 쉴 필요가 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gibuni an joayo, jogeum swil piryoga isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm not feeling well, I need to rest a bit.

examples.kr: 방이 조금 어둡습니다, 불을 켜주세요.
examples.romaji: Bangi jogeum eodubseubnida, bureul kyeojuseyo.
examples.en: The room is a bit dark, please turn on the light.

examples.kr: 짐이 너무 무거워요, 조금 줄여야 할 거 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jimyi neomu mugeowoyo, jogeum julyeoya hal geo gatayo.
examples.en: The luggage is too heavy, I think I need to lessen it a bit.

examples.kr: 그녀는 한국어를 조금 알아요, 그래서 간단한 대화는 가능해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun Hangugeoreul jogeum arayo, geuraeseo gandanhan daehwaneun ganeunghaeyo.
examples.en: She knows a little Korean, so simple conversation is possible.

title: 다 [da] (All, entirely)
short_explanation: Used to express the entirety or completeness of an action or state.
long_explanation: '다 [da]' is a predicate-final suffix used in Korean to indicate the full completion or totality of a subject or object's action, state, or condition. It implies that something was done completely, all of something was used, or that a particular state applies to everyone or everything. This can be similar to 'all', 'every', or 'entirely' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 공부하는 책을 다 읽었어요, 그래서 이제 뭐 읽을지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul gongbuhaneun chaekeul da ilgeosseoyo, geuraeseo ije mwo ilgeulji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I read all the books on studying Korean, so now I don't know what to read.

examples.kr: 우리 영화를 다 보고 나서야 집에 돌아갔어요.
examples.romaji: Uri yeonghwareul da bogo nasoya jibe doragasseoyo.
examples.en: We went home only after watching the entire movie.

examples.kr: 그녀는 한국에 오면서 한국음식을 다 좋아한다고 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hanguke omyeonseo hangugeumsigeul da joahandago malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: She said that she likes all Korean food after coming to Korea.

examples.kr: 이번 주 식료품을 다 사 왔어요, 그래서 주방에는 빈 칸이 하나도 없어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon ju sigryopumeul da sa wasseoyo, geuraeseo jubangeneun bin kani hanado eopseoyo.
examples.en: I bought all the groceries this week, so there is not a single empty spot in the kitchen.

title: (으)ㄴ/는데 [(eu)n/neunde] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '(으)ㄴ/는데 [(eu)n/neunde]' is used to indicate a contrast or contradiction in Korean sentences. It is similar to the English 'but' or 'however'. This grammar point is very commonly used in spoken and written Korean as it can link two clauses together in a smooth way. It can be used in negative and positive statements, and regardless of the level of formality.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋은데, 저는 집에만 있다가 나가고 싶지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga joheunneunde, jeoneun jibeman itdaga nagago sipji anhayo.
examples.en: The weather is nice today, but I just want to stay at home and don't want to go out.

examples.kr: 그는 매우 친절한데, 가끔은 너무 솔직해서 상처를 줄 때가 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun maewu chinjeolhaneunde, gakkeumeun neomu soljikhaeseo sangcheoreul jul ttaega isseoyo.
examples.en: He's very kind, but sometimes he's so honest that he can hurt.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어 공부를 오래한데도 불구하고 아직 많이 부족해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeo gongbureul oraehandeodo bulguhago ajik manhi bujokhaeyo.
examples.en: I have been studying Korean for a long time, but I'm still lacking a lot.

examples.kr: 이 옷은 예쁜데, 제 스타일이 아니에요.
examples.romaji: I otseun yeppeunneunde, je seutairi anieyo.
examples.en: This outfit is pretty, but it's not my style.

title: 아/어야 해요 [a/eoya haeyo] (Have to do)
short_explanation: Used to express the necessity or obligation to do something; 'have to', 'should', 'must'.
long_explanation: The grammar point '아/어야 해요 [a/eoya haeyo]' is used in Korean to express the need or requirement to do a certain action. It is used to emphasize an obligation or duty that one ought to do, similar to 'have to' or 'should' in English. This construction is particularly common in giving advice or stating something that must be done.
formation: Dictionary form of Verb + 아/어야 해요

examples.kr: 이렇게 많은 공부가 있으니까, 우리는 빨리 시작해야 해요, 그렇지 않으면 시간이 부족해져서 모든 것을 완료할 수 없습니다.
examples.romaji: Ireohke manheun gongbuga isseunikka, urineun ppalli sijakhaeya haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon sigani bujokhaejyeoseo modeun geoseul wanryohal su eopsseubnida.
examples.en: Since we have so much studying to do, we have to start quickly; otherwise, we won't have enough time to complete everything.

examples.kr: 주말에 시험이 있으므로, 저는 지금부터 준비해야 해요, 그만큼 공부하지 않으면 시험에 실패할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jumal-e siheom-i iss-eumyeo, jeoneun jigeumbuteo junbihaeya haeyo, geumankeum gongbuha-ji anh-eumyeon siheom-e silpaehal su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Since I have an exam this weekend, I have to prepare from now on, if I don't study that much, I might fail the exam.

examples.kr: 내일 회사에 아침 일찍 가야 해요, 중요한 회의 때문에 매우 중요하니까.
examples.romaji: Naeil hoesae achim iljjik gaya haeyo, jungyohan hoeyi ttaemune maewoo jungyohanikka.
examples.en: I have to go to the office early in the morning tomorrow because of an important meeting, which is very important.

examples.kr: 여름에는 SPF를 바르는 것이 중요하므로, 나가기 전에 항상 자외선 차단제를 바르아야 해요, 아니면 피부가 상할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yeoreumeneun SPFreul bareuneun geosi jung-yohamyeo, na-gagi jeone hangsang jawe-seon chadanje-reulbareoya haeyo, animyeon pibuga sanghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Since it is important to apply SPF in the summer, you always have to apply sunscreen before going out or else your skin might get damaged.

title: 안 [an] (Negation before verb/adjective)
short_explanation: Used to negate verbs and adjectives in Korean; 'not'.
long_explanation: '안 [an]' is a type of adverb used in Korean to negate verbs and adjectives. It holds the meaning of 'not' in English. By positioning '안 [an]' in front of a verb or adjective, it negates the meaning of that verb or adjective. Therefore, it fundamentally changes the meaning of the sentence by conveying the opposite of what the original verb or adjective meant.

examples.kr: 저는 아직 안 자요, 아직 일이 남았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ajik an jayo, ajik iri namasseoyo.
examples.en: I haven't slept yet, there is still work left.

examples.kr: 내 친구는 연어를 안 먹어요, 그녀는 생선을 좋아하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Nae chinguneun yeoneoreul an meogeoyo, geunyeoneun saengseoneul joahaji anhayo.
examples.en: My friend doesn't eat salmon, she doesn't like fish.

examples.kr: 너는 그 영화를 안 봤어요? 정말 재미있어요, 꼭 봐야 해요.
examples.romaji: Neoneun geu yeonghwareul an bwasseoyo? Jeongmal jaemiisseoyo, ggok bwaya haeyo.
examples.en: Haven't you watched that movie? It's really interesting, you must watch it.

examples.kr: 제가 그 사람을 진짜 안 좋아해요, 그는 항상 거짓말을 하니까요.
examples.romaji: Jega geu saramul jinjja an joahayeo, geuneun hangsang geojitmaleul hanikkayo.
examples.en: I really do not like that person, because he always tells lies.

title: 못 [mot] (Can't, not able to)
short_explanation: Used to express inability or impossibility; 'can't', 'not able to'.
long_explanation: '못 [mot]' is a Korean adverb used to indicate an inability or impossibility to do something. This is not always a physical inability, but can also be a matter of circumstance or permission, much like 'can't' or 'not able to' in English. It is typically used before an action verb to show that the action cannot or could not happen.

examples.kr: 오늘은 너무 피곤해서 저는 일찍 잠을 못 잤어요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun neomu pigonhaeseo jeoneun iljjik jameul mot jasseoyo.
examples.en: Today I was so tired that I couldn't sleep early.

examples.kr: 그녀는 많이 걱정해서 그리고 스트레스를 받아서 밥을 못 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun mani geokjeonghaeseo geurigo seuteureseureul badaseo babeul mot meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: She was so worried and stressed that she couldn't eat.

examples.kr: 비가 너무 많이 와서 우리는 놀이공원에 갈 수가 못 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Biga neomu mani waseo urineun noligongweone gal suga mot isseosseoyo.
examples.en: Because it rained so much, we couldn't go to the amusement park.

examples.kr: 저는 너무 늦게 와서 회의에 참석을 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun neomu neujge waseo hoeuie chamseogeul mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: I was too late to attend the meeting.

title: 아/어/여 보다 [a/eo/yeo boda] (Try doing)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express an attempt or an experience. It can be translated as 'try doing'.
long_explanation: The '아/어/여 보다' grammar point is used in Korean language to express trying something out or expressing that one has had an experience of doing something. It is always used with action verbs. It is important to note that the verb stem is used without any tense. The final verb '보다' carries the tense. Physical actions and actions related to taking in new information or experience are typically used with this grammar form.

examples.kr: 이 문제를 어떻게 해결할지 모르겠으면, 내 방식대로 한 번 해보아요.
examples.romaji: I munjereul eotteohge hae gyeolhalji moreugesseumyeon, nae bangshikdaero han beon haeboayo.
examples.en: If you don't know how to solve this problem, you should try doing it my way.

examples.kr: 김치를 만들어 본 적이 없다면, 한번 시도해보세요. 정말 쉽고 재미있어요.
examples.romaji: Kimchireul mandeureo bon jeogi eopdamyeon, hanbeon sidohae boseyo. Jeongmal swipgo jaemi isseoyo.
examples.en: If you've never tried making kimchi, give it a go. It's really easy and fun.

examples.kr: 예전에 한국어를 배워 보았지만, 전혀 기억이 안나요
examples.romaji: Yejeon-e hangugeoleul baewo bonatjiman, jeonhyeo gi-eogi annayo.
examples.en: I've tried to learn Korean before, but I remember nothing.

examples.kr: 이 방법으로 공부해보았는데, 결과가 아주 좋았어요.
examples.romaji: I bangbeob-euro gongbuhabeonatneunde, gyeolgwa-ga aju joass-eoyo.
examples.en: I tried studying this way, and the results were very good.

title: 지금 [jigeum] (Now)
short_explanation: Used to refer to 'now' or the 'current moment'.
long_explanation: '지금 [jigeum]' is a common word in Korean that is used to reference the present moment or the immediate situation. It's equivalent to the word 'now' in English. It's often used when describing current actions, states, or situations. Depending on the context, it may refer to a specific moment, the present day, or even a broader period of time.
formation: 지금 (Often used at the start of a sentence or before verbs)

examples.kr: 지금 학교에 가야 해요, 수업이 곧 시작될 것이에요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum hakgyo-e gaya haeyo, sueopi got sijakdoel geos-ieyo.
examples.en: I have to go to school now, the class is about to start.

examples.kr: 지금 비가 오고 있어요, 우산을 가져가는 것이 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum biga ogo isseoyo, usaneul gajyeoganeun geosi joheul geot gatayo.
examples.en: It's raining now, it would be good to take an umbrella.

examples.kr: 지금 숙제를 하고 있어요, 나중에 전화할게요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum sukjereul hago isseoyo, najung-e jeonhwahalgeyo.
examples.en: I am doing my homework now, I'll call you later.

examples.kr: 지금 저희 집에 오시면 식사를 같이 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum jeoheui jib-e osimyeon sigsareul gati hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: If you come to my house now, we can have a meal together.

title: 이미 [imi] (Already)
short_explanation: Used to express an action that has already taken place.
long_explanation: '이미 [imi]' is a Korean adverb used to indicate that an action or situation has occurred in the past. It can directly translate to 'already' in English. This adverb is typically used when an event or action has occurred earlier than someone might think or earlier than expected.

examples.kr: 너는 이미 그 영화를 보았기 때문에, 멍청하게 또 보러가는 것은 무슨 의미가 있을까요?
examples.romaji: Neoneun imi geu yeonghwaleul boassgii ttaemune, meongcheonghage tto boreoganeun geosun museun uimiga isseulgga?
examples.en: What's the point of you going to see the movie again stupidly since you have already seen it?

examples.kr: 전 이미 저녁을 먹었으니, 당신은 혼자 저녁을 먹으세요.
examples.romaji: Jeon imi jeonyeogeul meogeosseuni, dangsineun honja jeonyeogeul meogeuseyo.
examples.en: Since I have already eaten dinner, you should have dinner by yourself.

examples.kr: 작년에 이미 그 회사의 주식을 팔았기 때문에, 이제는 아무런 손실도 없습니다.
examples.romaji: Jaknyeone imi geu hoesaui jusigeul palassgi ttaemune, ijeneun amureon sonsilro eopseumneda.
examples.en: Since I have already sold the stocks of that company last year, there is no loss now.

examples.kr: 이곳에 왔을 때, 해는 이미 떠 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Igose watseul ttae, haneun imi tteo isseosseoyo.
examples.en: When I came here, the sun had aready risen.

title: 아직 [ajik] (Yet, still)
short_explanation: Used to express that a condition or situation is ongoing; 'yet', 'still'.
long_explanation: '아직 [ajik]' is commonly used in Korean to indicate that a particular situation or condition is ongoing or has not changed. It is a straightforward way of expressing the idea of 'yet' or 'still' in English. It is usually used in the beginning, middle, or end of a sentence, and often, it is used with negative and past tense verbs. This grammar point helps to signify a duration of an action or a state that persists without being completed or altered.

examples.kr: 아직 저는 한국어를 완벽하게 잘 못 이해해요, 계속 연습이 필요해요.
examples.romaji: Ajik jeoneun hangugeoreul wanbyeokhage jal mot ihaehaeyo, gyesok yeonseub-i piryohaeyo.
examples.en: I still cannot understand Korean perfectly well, I need to keep practicing.

examples.kr: 결정할 수 있어도, 아직 그에 대해 생각하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gyeoljeonghal su iss-eodo, ajik geu-e daehae saeng-gag-hago iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Even though I can make a decision, I'm still thinking about it.

examples.kr: 아직 그 영화를 보지 않았어요, 주말에 볼 예정이에요.
examples.romaji: Ajik geu yeonghwaleul boji anh-ass-eoyo, jumal-e bol yejeong-ieyo.
examples.en: I have not watched that movie yet, I plan to watch it on the weekend.

examples.kr: 아직 점심을 먹지 않았어요, 배가 너무 고프네요.
examples.romaji: Ajik jeomsim-eul meogji anh-ass-eoyo, baega neomu gopeuneyo.
examples.en: I have not yet had lunch, I'm really hungry.

title: 때 [ttae] (When, time)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a specific time or moment; 'when', 'time'.
long_explanation: '때 [ttae]' is a noun in Korean which is used to refer to a specific time or moment. It can be used in a variety of contexts to express 'when' something happens or 'at the time' something happened. It often comes after a verb-stem or a noun to indicate the time 'when' an action takes place or a situation occurs. This is a versatile word that you will see often in many different types of sentences.

examples.kr: 저는 작은 때부터 한국어를 배우고 싶어했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jageun ttaebuteo hangugeoreul baeugo sipeohaesseoyo.
examples.en: I have wanted to learn Korean since I was young.

examples.kr: 그 여자가 웃을 때, 저는 정말로 행복해요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeojaga useul ttae, jeoneun jeongmallo haengbokhaeyo.
examples.en: When that woman smiles, I am truly happy.

examples.kr: 첫 만남의 때, 그를 절대로 잊지 못할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Cheot mannamui ttae, geureul jeoldaero itji mothael geoyeyo.
examples.en: When we first met, I will never forget him.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 여행을 가고 싶은데, 시간이 없을 때 어떻게 해야 할까요?
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumal-e yeohaeng-eul gago sip-eunde, sigan-i eobs-eul ttae eotteohge haeya halkkayo?
examples.en: I want to go on a trip this weekend, but what should I do when I don't have time?

title: (으)려고 하다 [(eu)ryeogo hada] (Intend to do)
short_explanation: Used to express the intention or plan to do something.
long_explanation: '(으)려고 하다 [(eu)ryeogo hada]' is a grammar point that expresses intention or plan to do something in the near or distant future. It is used to show a forward-looking intent, that is, an intention or plan that has not been executed yet.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 더 잘 하기 위해 노력하려고 합니다, 많은 연습을 통해 제 기술을 향상시키려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul deo jal hagi wihae noryeokharyeogo habnida, manheun yeonseubeul tonghae je gisuleul hyangsangsikiryogo habnida.
examples.en: I intend to work hard to improve my Korean, I plan to enhance my skills through lots of practice.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 오려고 하니 우산을 챙기려고 합니다, 건강을 위해 감기를 방지하려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga oryeogo hani usaneul chaenggiryogo habnida, geongangeul wihae gamgireul bangjiharyeogo habnida.
examples.en: I'm planning to take an umbrella because it's going to rain tomorrow; I intend to prevent cold for my health.

examples.kr: 친구와 함께 여행을 가려고 합니다, 함께 좋은 시간을 보내려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Chinguwa hamkke yeohaengeul garyeogo habnida, hamkke joheun siganeul bonaeryeogo habnida.
examples.en: I intend to go on a trip with my friend; I plan to have a good time together.

examples.kr: 그녀는 다음달에 결혼 준비를 하려고 합니다, 모든 것이 완벽하게 되려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun daeumdale gyeolhon junbireul haryeogo habnida, modeun geosi wanbyeokhage doeryeogo habnida.
examples.en: She plans to prepare for her wedding next month; She intends for everything to be perfect.

title: 처럼 [cheoreom] (Like, as)
short_explanation: This postposition is used to express similarity, comparison, or metaphor, similar to 'like' or 'as' in English.
long_explanation: '처럼 [cheoreom]' is a postposition in Korean that indicates similarity or comparison to the preceding noun. It is usually used to compare two things, express that one thing acts or functions as another thing, or to say that something is done in the same way as something else. It can also be used in metaphorical expressions.

examples.kr: 그는 사자처럼 강해 보였어요, 그런데 실제로는 그렇게 강하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun sajacheoreom ganghae boyeosseoyo, geureonde siljeroeun geureohge ganghaji anhayo.
examples.en: He seemed strong like a lion, but in reality, he's not that strong.

examples.kr: 우리 친구는 항상 별처럼 빛나요, 그녀는 정말로 모두에게 사랑받는 사람이에요.
examples.romaji: Uri chinguneun hangsang byeolcheoreom bitnayo, geunyeoneun jeongmallo modeuege sarangbatneun sarameyo.
examples.en: Our friend always shines like a star; she is truly a person loved by everyone.

examples.kr: 그녀는 나비처럼 춤을 춰요. 그녀의 춤은 정말로 아름답고 유려해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun nabicheoreom chumeul chwoyo. Geunyeoui chumeun jeongmallo areumdapgo yuryehaeyo.
examples.en: She dances like a butterfly. Her dance is really beautiful and graceful.

examples.kr: 그는 독수리처럼 높이 날아갔어요, 그의 비행은 정말로 인상적이었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun doksuricheoreom nopi naragasseoyo, geuui bihaengeun jeongmalro insangjeogieosseoyo.
examples.en: He flew high like an eagle, his flight was really impressive.

title: 같이 [gachi] (Together)
short_explanation: This is used to express 'together' or 'along with'.
long_explanation: '같이 [gachi]' is a Korean adverb that is used to indicate doing something 'together' or 'along with' someone else. It adds the meaning of companionship or co-action to the verb in the sentence. It can be attached after a noun directly without a space.

examples.kr: 제 친구와 같이 영화를 보러 갔어요. 짱짱 재미 있었어요!
examples.romaji: Je chinguwa gachi yeonghwareul boreo gasseoyo. Jjangjjang jaemi isseosseoyo!
examples.en: I went to see a movie with my friend. It was really fun!

examples.kr: 내일은 우리 모두 같이 공원에 가서 피크닉을 하기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Naeireun uri modu gachi gongwone gaseo pikeunikeul hagiro haesseoyo.
examples.en: We decided to all go to the park and have a picnic together tomorrow.

examples.kr: 엄마와 같이 요리하면 항상 더 맛있는 음식을 만들 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Umma wa gachi yorihamyun hangsang deo mashitneun eumsigeul mandeul su isseoyo.
examples.en: If I cook with my mom, I can always make more delicious food.

examples.kr: 과외 선생님과 같이 공부하면 많은 도움이 되요.
examples.romaji: Gwaoe seonsaengnim gwa gachi gongbuhamyun manheun doumi dweyo.
examples.en: Studying with a private tutor is very helpful.

title: (이)랑 [(i)rang] (With)
short_explanation: Used to express 'with' or 'and' when referring to being together or doing something together.
long_explanation: '(이)랑 [(i)rang]' is a conjunctive particle used in Korean language to denote the concept of 'with' or 'and'. It connotes a sense of togetherness or association, indicating that the subject is together with or doing something together with someone or something else. In case of nouns ending with a vowel, '랑 [rang]' is used while '이랑 [irang]' is used if the noun ends with a consonant.
formation: If noun ends with a vowel: Noun + 랑 [rang] / If noun ends with a consonant: Noun + 이랑 [irang]

examples.kr: 제가 친구랑 영화를 봤어요, 그 영화는 재미있었어요.
examples.romaji: Jega chingurang yeonghwaleul bwasseoyo, geu yeonghwaneun jaemiisseosseoyo.
examples.en: I watched a movie with a friend, that movie was interesting.

examples.kr: 어제 저는 엄마랑 장을 보러 갔어요, 우리는 많은 식료품을 샀어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje jeoneun eommarang jangeul boreo gasseoyo, urineun maneun sikryopumeul sasseoyo.
examples.en: Yesterday, I went to the market with my mom, we bought a lot of groceries.

examples.kr: 나는 동생이랑 공원에서 놀았어요, 우리는 많이 즐거웠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun dongsaengirang gongwoneseo norasseoyo, urineun mani jeulgeowosseoyo.
examples.en: I played in the park with my younger sibling, we had a lot of fun.

examples.kr: 오늘 점심시간에 친구이랑 음악을 들었어요, 그 음악이 너무 좋았어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeomsimsigan-e chinguirang eumag-eul deuleoss-eoyo, geu eumag-i neomu joass-eoyo.
examples.en: At lunchtime today, I listened to music with a friend, the music was very good.

title: 그런데 [geureonde] (However, but)
short_explanation: Used to indicate contrast or contradiction; 'however', 'but'.
long_explanation: '그런데 [geureonde]' is a transitional phrase used in Korean to introduce a statement that contradicts or contrasts with what has been said before. It is often used to express a different perspective, a contrary situation, or a conflicting feeling. This conjunction can be translated as 'however', 'but', or 'though' in English.

examples.kr: 처음에는 그 과제가 쉬워 보였어요, 그런데 실제로 해보니 매우 어려웠어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeumeneun geu gwaje ga swiweo boyeosseoyo, geureonde siljero hae boni maeu eoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: At first, the assignment seemed easy, but when I actually did it, it was very difficult.

examples.kr: 저는 가장 좋아하는 스포츠가 농구인데, 그런데 제 친구는 농구를 전혀 좋아하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gajang joahaneun seupocheuga nongguinde, geureonde je chinguneun nonggureul jeonhyeo joahaji anhayo.
examples.en: My favorite sport is basketball, but my friend does not like basketball at all.

examples.kr: 어제 영화관에 갔는데, 그런데 영화가 이미 시작된 후였어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje yeonghwagwane gassneunde, geureonde yeonghwaga imi sijakdoen hueosseoyo.
examples.en: I went to the cinema yesterday, but the movie had already started.

examples.kr: 친구가 이 청바지를 추천해 줬는데, 그런데 제 스타일에 맞지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga i cheongbajireul chucheonhae junneunde, geureonde je seutaire matji anhayo.
examples.en: My friend recommended these jeans to me, but they do not suit my style.

title: 그래서 [geuraeseo] (So, therefore)
short_explanation: Used to express cause and effect; 'so', 'therefore'.
long_explanation: '그래서 [geuraeseo]' is a conjunctive adverb used in Korean to provide a logical outcome or conclusion from a given situation or event, similar to 'so' or 'therefore' in English. It is used to connect two sentences where the second sentence is the result or outcome of the first sentence. Used primarily in informal speech but can be used in written language and formal speech with discretion.

examples.kr: 오늘은 간단하게 먹으려고 했는데, 친구가 맛있는 음식을 가지고 왔어요. 그래서 많이 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun gandanage meogeuryeogo haetneunde, chinguga masissneun eumsigeul gajigo wassseubnida. geuraeseo manhi meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was planning to eat simply today, but my friend brought delicious food. So, I ate a lot.

examples.kr: 전 책을 읽는 것을 좋아해요. 그래서 한 달에 여러 권의 책을 읽어요.
examples.romaji: Jeon chaegeul ilgneun geoseul joahaeyo. geuraeseo han dale yeoreo gwonui chaegireul ilgeoyo.
examples.en: I like reading books. So, I read several books every month.

examples.kr: 어제 공부를 너무 많이 했어요. 그래서 오늘은 쉬어야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje gongbureul neomu mani haesseoyo. geuraeseo oneureun swieoyagessseubnida.
examples.en: I studied too much yesterday. So, I should rest today.

examples.kr: 주말에는 늦게까지 자서 깨어나지 못 했어요. 그래서 점심이 되어 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Jumaleneun neutgekkaji jaseo kkaeeonaji mot haesseoyo. geuraeseo jeomsimi doeeo beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I couldn't wake up on weekend because I slept late. So, it became lunch time.

title: 그리고 [geurigo] (And then)
short_explanation: This connector is used to link actions, situations or phases that occur consecutively.
long_explanation: '그리고 [geurigo]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate sequential occurrences of actions or situations. It conveys a sense of continuation or succession, akin to 'and then' in English. It is used to emphasize the sequential flow of events and is often used in complex sentences to describe actions or situations of a similar nature or time order.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에 갔어요 그리고 수업을 들었어요 그리고 친구들과 점심을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoe gasseoyo geurigo sueopeul deuleosseoyo geurigo chingudeulgwa jeomsimeul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I went to school, and then I took classes, and then I had lunch with friends.

examples.kr: 게임을 했어요 그리고 졸려서 잠을 잤어요 그리고 다시 게임을 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geimeul haesseoyo geurigo jollyeosseo jam-eul jasseoyo geurigo dasi geimeul haesseoyo.
examples.en: I played a game, and then I fell asleep because I was sleepy, and then I played the game again.

examples.kr: 제가 커피를 마셨어요 그리고 도서관에 갔어요 그리고 공부를 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jega keopireul masyeosseoyo geurigo doseogwane gaseoyo geurigo gongbureul haesseoyo.
examples.en: I drank coffee, and then I went to the library, and then I studied.

examples.kr: 친구를 만났어요 그리고 영화를 봤어요 그리고 집에 돌아왔어요.
examples.romaji: Chingureul mannasseoyo geurigo yeonghwareul bwasseoyo geurigo jibe dolawasseoyo.
examples.en: I met a friend, and then I watched a movie, and then I came home.

title: 아/어/여 주다 [a/eo/yeo juda] (To do for someone)
short_explanation: Used to express the act of doing something for someone.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 주다 [a/eo/yeo juda]' is a verb ending used in Korean to express the action of doing something for someone else. It is formed by attaching 아/어/여 to the stem of an action verb, followed by 주다. The resulting phrase conveys the idea of the subject performing the action on behalf of or for the benefit of someone else. This is often used to express kindness, favor, or doing something for someone else's convenience or benefit.

examples.kr: 제가 수업 노트를 정리해서 친구에게 메일로 보내주었어요.
examples.romaji: Je-ga su-eop noteu-reul jeongrihaeseo chinguege meillo bonaejueoss-eoyo.
examples.en: I organized the class notes and sent them to my friend by email.

examples.kr: 서민이가 청소를 해주는 것을 본 후, 결국 나도 청소를 도와주었어요.
examples.romaji: Seomin-iga cheongso-reul haejuneun geoseul bon hu, gyeolguk nado cheongso-reul dowajueoss-eoyo.
examples.en: After seeing Seomin cleaning, I ended up helping with the cleaning too.

examples.kr: 어려운 문제 때문에 고민하다가, 선생님이 해결 방법을 알려주었어요.
examples.romaji: Eoryeoun munje ttaemune gominhada-ga, seonsaengnim-i haegyeol bangbeob-eul allyeojueoss-eoyo.
examples.en: I was worrying about a difficult problem, then the teacher told me the solution.

examples.kr: 맛있는 음식을 해서 친구들에게 저녁을 챙겨주는 걸 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Masissneun eumsik-eul haeseo chingudeul-ege jeonyeog-eul chaenggyeojuneun geol johahae-yo.
examples.en: I like making delicious food and serving dinner to my friends.

title: 아/어/여 하다 [a/eo/yeo hada] (Do something)
short_explanation: Used to signify making an effort or taking an action to make something happen.
long_explanation: "아/어/여 하다 [a/eo/yeo hada]" is a Korean grammar construction used to imply the act of responding or acting with the purpose of creating a reaction or outcome. It gives the nuance of actively doing something or taking the necessary steps to achieve a certain result. It’s mostly used with subjective experience verbs. The verb form that is used depends on the preceding vowel in the verb stem and it is usually attached to native Korean verbs.

examples.kr: 우리가 창문을 열어두고 한밤중에 야외 파티를 해하면서 이웃들로부터 불만을 유발했습니다.
examples.romaji: Uriga changmuneul yeoleodugo hanbamjunge yaoe patireul haehamyeonseo iutdeullobuteo bulmaneul yubalhaetseubnida.
examples.en: By leaving the window open and having an outdoor party in the middle of the night, we caused complaints from our neighbors.

examples.kr: 그녀는 재미있는 이야기를 들려 하여 사람들을 웃게 만드는데 매력이 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jaemiinneun iyagireul deullyeo hae yeo saramdeuleul utge mandeuneunde maeryeogi isseumnida.
examples.en: She has the charm of making people laugh by telling interesting stories.

examples.kr: 동생에게 숙제를 도와 해준 후에야 저는 제 방에 들어갈 수 있었습니다.
examples.romaji: Dongsaengege sukje reul dowahae jun hueya jeoneun je bange deuleogal su isseotseumnida.
examples.en: Only after helping my younger sibling with his homework, I could finally go to my room.

examples.kr: 경량 기계 운동을 해 하여 체력을 향상시키는 것이 필요한 최근의 일입니다.
examples.romaji: gyeongryang gige undongeul haehae cheryeogeul hyangsang sikineun geosi piryo han choegeunui irida.
examples.en: Doing lightweight machine exercises to improve physical fitness is a recent necessity.

title: 의 [ui] (Possessive marker)
short_explanation: Used to denote possession or relatedness; 's, of.'
long_explanation: The word '의 [ui]' is a possession indicator in Korean, much like 's' used for possessiveness in English. This particle is usually positioned between two nouns to illustrate a relationship between those two, such as ownership, belonging or being a part of something. It doesn't only mark ownership, but can indicate a subject belonging to a certain category, origin, or describing the material something is made of.

examples.kr: 이것은 나의 책이에요, 따라서 그것을 누군가에게 주지 않을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun naui chaegieyo, ttaraseo geugeoseul nugungaege juji anheul geoyeyo.
examples.en: This is my book, so I'm not going to give it to anyone.

examples.kr: 부탁드려요, 저의 주차 공간을 차지하지 말아 주세요.
examples.romaji: Butakdeuryeoyo, jeoui jucha gongganeul chajihaji mara juseyo.
examples.en: Please, do not occupy my parking space.

examples.kr: 그녀는 그녀의 강아지를 참으로 사랑합니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun geunyeoui gangajireul chameuro saranghabnida.
examples.en: She really loves her puppy.

examples.kr: 이것은 그의 아버지의 오래된 시계입니다.
examples.romaji: Igoseun geuui abeojiui oraedoen sigyeibnida.
examples.en: This is his father's old watch.

title: (으)로 [(eu)ro] (To, toward; as a tool/method)
short_explanation: Used to express direction, means / method, transformation, and purpose
long_explanation: '(으)로 [(eu)ro]' is a postposition in Korean language that is used to express various types of information such as direction (to, toward), means or method (by, with, using), transformation (into), and purpose. This particle is attached directly to a noun if the noun ends in a vowel and becomes '으로' if the noun ends with a consonant. The usage widely depends on the context.

examples.kr: 나는 매일 아침 지하철로 학교에 가요.
examples.romaji: Naneun maeil achim jihacheollo hakgyoe gayo.
examples.en: I go to school by subway every morning.

examples.kr: 우리 아빠는 요리를 재료로 사랑을 표현해요.
examples.romaji: Uri appaneun yorireul jaeryoro sarangeul pyohyeonhaeyo.
examples.en: My father expresses his love through cooking ingredients.

examples.kr: 그 회사는 종이를 재활용해서 노트북으로 만들어요.
examples.romaji: Geu hoesaneun jongireul jaehwallyonghaeseo noteubugeuro mandeuleoyo.
examples.en: The company recycles paper into notebooks.

examples.kr: 문을 열기 위해 열쇠로 문을 돌려요.
examples.romaji: Muneul yeolgi wihae yeolswero muneul dollyeoyo.
examples.en: I turn the key in the lock to open the door.

title: 한테/에게 [hante/ege] (To someone)
short_explanation: These phrases indicate to whom an action is directed or who is the receiver of an action.
long_explanation: '한테 [hante]' and '에게 [ege]' are used in Korean to indicate the action's recipient or direction. It can be compared to 'to' in English when giving something to someone or doing something to someone. While '에게 [ege]' is more formal, '한테 [hante]' is more often used colloquially.

examples.kr: 제가 어제 친구에게 선물을 줬어요.
examples.romaji: Jega eoje chinguege seonmul-eul jwosseoyo.
examples.en: I gave a gift to my friend yesterday.

examples.kr: 제 목소리를 직접 그녀에게 들려주고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Je mogsorireul jikjeop geunyeoege deullyeojugo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to let her hear my voice directly.

examples.kr: 언니한테 좋은 뉴스를 전하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Eonni-hante joheun nyuseureul jeonhago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to convey good news to my older sister.

examples.kr: 어머니한테 저녁 식사를 준비해드렸어요.
examples.romaji: Eomeoni-hante jeonyeok siksa-reul junbi-haedyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I prepared dinner for my mother.

title: 한테서/에서 [hanteseo/eseo] (From someone)
short_explanation: Used to denote the source or origin; 'from'.
long_explanation: '한테서/에서 [hanteseo/eseo]' is a location particle in Korean language which signifies the source, place, or person from which something originates or comes from. It can be used in various contexts to indicate the source of an object or the starting location of a movement. Usually '에서 [eseo]' is used with inanimate objects or places, while '한테서 [hanteseo]' is used with persons.

examples.kr: 친구한테서 편지를 받았어요. 그는 항상 연락을 잘해줘요.
examples.romaji: Chinguhanteseo pyeonjireul badasseoyo. Geuneun hangsang yeollageul jalhaejwoyo.
examples.en: I received a letter from a friend. He always keeps in touch well.

examples.kr: 서울에서 부산까지 차로 얼마나 걸릴까요?
examples.romaji: Seouleseo Busankkaji chalo eolmana geollilkka yo?
examples.en: How long does it take by car from Seoul to Busan?

examples.kr: 제가 이 책을 도서관에서 빌렸어요.
examples.romaji: Jega i chaegeul doseogwaneseo billyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I borrowed this book from the library.

examples.kr: 그 음식은 어머니한테서 배웠어요.
examples.romaji: Geu eumsikeun eomeonihanteseo baeweossseubnida.
examples.en: I learned how to cook that dish from mother.

title: 보다 [boda] (More than)
short_explanation: Used to express comparison, meaning 'more than' or 'than'.
long_explanation: '보다 [boda]' is a comparative marker in Korean language. It is used to express comparison between two subjects or to indicate the superiority of one thing over another in certain aspects. The phrase before '보다' is superior in some way to the phrase after '보다'. In English, it features the same concept as 'more than' or 'than'.

examples.kr: 저는 커피보다 차를 더 좋아합니다, 커피보다 차가 제 입맛에 더 잘 맞아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopiboda chareul deo johahamnida, keopiboda chaga je ibmase deo jal majayo.
examples.en: I prefer tea over coffee, tea suits my taste more than coffee.

examples.kr: 우리 집은 도서관보다 책이 더 많아요, 가족 모두가 독서를 사랑해서 그렇게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Uri jibeun doseogwanboda chaegi deo manhayo, gajok moduga dokseoreul saranghaeseo geureohge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: We have more books at home than in a library, all because every member of our family loves reading.

examples.kr: 한국어를 배우는 것은 중국어를 배우는 것보다 쉬워요, 필기와 발음이 더 단순하니까요.
examples.romaji: Hangug-eoreul baeuneun geoseun junggugeoreul baeuneun geosboda swiwoyo, pilgiwa bal-eum-i deo dansunhanigga-yo.
examples.en: Learning Korean is easier than learning Chinese, because the writing and pronunciation are simpler.

examples.kr: 지금은 여름이지만, 여전히 봄보다 날씨가 추워요, 이상한 기후 변화 때문인 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum-eun yeoreum-ijiman, yeojeonhi bomboda nalssiga chuwoyo, isanghan gihu byeonhwa ttaemun-in geos gat-ayo.
examples.en: It's summer now, but the weather is still colder than spring, it seems because of strange climate change.

title: 가장 [gajang] (The most)
short_explanation: Used to express the superlative degree; 'the most', 'the best'.
long_explanation: '가장 [gajang]' is a Korean adverb used to express the highest degree or extreme limit of an action, quality, or state. It's equivalent to 'most' or 'the most' in English. Compared to other things, the following adjective or noun shows maximum, highest, or extreme characteristics. It can be used with both positive and negative adjectives or adverbs.

examples.kr: 저는 가장 좋아하는 사람과 결혼하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gajang joahaneun saramgwa gyeolhonhago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to marry the person I love the most.

examples.kr: 가장 먼저 도착한 사람이 상품을 받을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gajang meonjeo dochakhan sarami sangpum-eul bad-eul su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: The person who arrives first will be able to receive the prize.

examples.kr: 그는 가장 힘들었던 시절에도 포기하지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gajang himdeul-eossdeon sijeol-edo pogihaji anh-ass-eoyo.
examples.en: Even during his hardest times, he didn't give up.

examples.kr: 저는 가장 큰 꿈을 이루고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gajang keun kkum-eul ilugo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to achieve my biggest dream.

title: 도 [do] (Even)
short_explanation: Used to emphasize a condition; 'even', 'also', 'too'.
long_explanation: '도 [do]' is a particle that is used to emphasize a condition or situation, similar to 'even' in English. It can be used after a noun, pronoun, or even a verb to indicate that the action or state also applies to the object or subject mentioned, similar to 'too' or 'also' in English. It highlights inclusion, extremity or unexpected situations, depending on the context.

examples.kr: 나는 한국어도 잘하고, 일본어도 잘해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangugeodo jalhago, ilboneodo jalhaeyo.
examples.en: I speak both Korean and Japanese very well.

examples.kr: 그는 잘생겼을 뿐만 아니라 성격도 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jalsaenggyeosseul bbunman anira seongkyeokdo joayo.
examples.en: Not only is he handsome, but he also has a good personality.

examples.kr: 이 식당은 음식도 맛있고, 분위기도 좋아요.
examples.romaji: I sikdangeun eumsikdo masitgo, bunwigido joayo.
examples.en: This restaurant not only serves delicious food, but also has a good atmosphere.

examples.kr: 나는 어제 집에 도착했을 때 밤 12시도 넘었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoje jibe dochakhaisseul ttae bam 12sido neomeosseoyo.
examples.en: When I arrived home yesterday, it was even past midnight.

title: 이/그/저 [i/geu/jeo] (This, that, that over there)
short_explanation: Used to indicate spatial relationship of the speaker to the subject matter; 'this', 'that', 'that over there'.
long_explanation: '이/그/저' are demonstrative pronouns used in Korean to specify the spatial relationship of subject matter to the speaker. '이' refers to something close to the speaker, translated as 'this'. '그' refers to something that is not near the speaker or the listener, translated as 'that'. '저' refers to something far from both the speaker and the listener, translated as 'that over there'.

examples.kr: 이 펜은 제 펜입니다. 그 펜은 당신의 펜입니다. 저 펜은 누구의 펜인지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: I pen-eun je pen-imnida. Geu pen-eun dangsin-ui pen-imnida. Jeo pen-eun nugu-ui pen-inji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: This pen is my pen. That pen is your pen. I don't know whose pen that over there is.

examples.kr: 이 핸드폰은 버그가 많아요. 그 핸드폰은 성능이 좋아요. 저 핸드폰은 무슨 모델인지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: I haendeupon-eun beogeu-ga manhayo. Geu haendeupon-eun seong-neung-i joahyo. Jeo haendeupon-eun museun model-inji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: This phone has many bugs. That phone has good performance. I don't know what model that phone over there is.

examples.kr: 이 음식은 맛이 없어요. 그 음식은 매워요. 저 음식은 어떤 맛인지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: I eumsik-eun mas-i eobseoyo. Geu eumsik-eun maewoyo. Jeo eumsik-eun eoddeon mas-inji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: This food has no taste. That food is spicy. I don't know what that food over there tastes like.

examples.kr: 이 책은 재미있어요. 그 책은 너무 어려워요. 저 책은 어떤 내용인지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: I chaek-eun jaemiisseoyo. Geu chaek-eun neomu eoryeowoyo. Jeo chaek-eun eoddeon naeyong-inji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: This book is interesting. That book is too difficult. I don't know what that book over there is about.

title: (이)나 [(i)na] (Or)
short_explanation: Used to express alternatives; 'or'.
long_explanation: '(이)나 [(i)na]' is a connective particle used in Korean to suggest alternative options or choices. It is similar to 'or' in English. This grammar point is often used to give or ask for choices between two or more items or situations. It can also be used after a verb to express doing something else in addition to the mentioned action.

examples.kr: 피자나 햄버거 중에 무엇을 먹고 싶어요?
examples.romaji: Pijana haembeogeo junge mueoseul meokgo sip-eoyo?
examples.en: Do you want to eat pizza or a hamburger?

examples.kr: 저는 주말에 친구들이랑 영화보러 가거나 쇼핑을 하러 갈 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jumare chingudeulirang yeonghwaboreo gageona syopingeul hareo gal geoyeyo.
examples.en: I'll go to watch a movie with my friends or go shopping on the weekend.

examples.kr: 빨래나 설거지 같은 집안일을 해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Ppallaena seolgeoji gateun jibanil-eul haeya haeyo.
examples.en: I have to do household chores like laundry or dishes.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에는 숙제를 하거나 책을 읽을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Oneul bameun sukjeleul hageona chaegeul ilgeul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Tonight, I will do homework or read a book.

title: 밖에 [bakke] (Only, except)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express 'only' or 'except by indicating a limitation or exclusiveness.
long_explanation: '밖에 [bakke]' is used after a noun to imply that there is nothing else except or but the noun. It is commonly used with negative sentences to express the absence of other options, alternatives, or possibilities except for the one mentioned. It represents the exclusiveness or limitation and similar to expressions including 'only', 'just', 'except' in English.

examples.kr: 나는 이번 주말에 집에 있을 수밖에 없었어요, 모든 친구들이 바쁘기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ibeon jumare jibe isseul subakke eopseosseoyo, modeun chingudeuli bappugi ttaemunieyo.
examples.en: I only could stay at home this weekend because all my friends were busy.

examples.kr: 엄마는 부엌에서 요리하는 것밖에 몰라서 다른 일을 할 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun buokeseo yorihaneun geosbakke mollaseo dareun ileul hal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: My mom could not do anything else except cooking in the kitchen.

examples.kr: 나는 한국어밖에 알지 못해서, 다른 언어로 이야기하는 것은 어렵습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangug-eo bakke alji mot-haeseo, dareun eon-eoro iyagihaneun geoseun eoryeobseubnida.
examples.en: I only know Korean, so it's hard to speak in other languages.

examples.kr: 그 학생은 공부밖에 몰라서 놀라고 다른 일은 잘 못해요.
examples.romaji: Geu haksaengeun gongbubakke mollaseo nolradeon dareun ireun jal mothyo.
examples.en: That student only knows to study, so it is hard for him to play and do other things.

title: 뿐 [ppun] (Only)
short_explanation: Used to express that 'only' a certain thing is the case.
long_explanation: '뿐 [ppun]' is a postposition used in Korean to indicate that 'only' the mentioned subject or object is the case. Slightly similar to '밖에 [bakke]', however, '뿐' is used in positive sentences to show that 'only' the condition stated is true or valid and it doesn't require a negative verb in the sentence. It helps stress the paucity, singleton or exclusiveness of something.

examples.kr: 우리 집에는 고양이 두 마리 뿐이에요, 다른 애완동물은 없어요.
examples.romaji: Uri jibeun goyangi du mari ppunieyo, dareun aewandongmuleun eopseoyo.
examples.en: There are only two cats in our house, there are no other pets.

examples.kr: 주말에는 집에서 휴식하는 것 뿐이지, 특별한 일정은 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jumaleneun jibeseo hyusikhaneun geot ppuniji, teukbyeolhan iljeongeun eopseoyo.
examples.en: On weekends, I only rest at home, I have no special schedule.

examples.kr: 저는 커피 뿐 아니라 차도 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopi ppun anira chado joahaeyo.
examples.en: I like not only coffee but also tea.

examples.kr: 그리고 이것이 저의 한계입니다, 더 이상 할 수 있는 것은 없습니다, 저는 최선을 다 했을 뿐입니다.
examples.romaji: Geurigo igeosi jeoui hangyeipnida, deo isang hal su issneun geoseun eopseumnida, jeoneun choeseoneul da haesseul ppunimnida.
examples.en: And this is my limit, there is nothing more I can do, I have done my best only.

title: 는/은 것 [neun/eun geot] (The thing that, nominalizing)
short_explanation: Used to nominalize verbs or adjectives; 'the (thing) that', 'doing' or 'being'.
long_explanation: '는/은 것 [neun/eun geot]' is a grammatical construction used in Korean to nominalize or turn verbs or adjectives into nouns. This form is often used as a general reference to a situation or an action, or to make abstract ideas concrete. It translates as 'the thing that', 'doing' or 'being' in English. It is often used in sentences to express an action or state happening in the generalized or specific context.

examples.kr: 영화를 보는 것이 왜 그렇게 재미있는지 이해할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwareul boneun geosi wae geureohge jaemiissneunji ihaehal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I cannot understand why watching movies is so interesting.

examples.kr: 우리 나라에 사는 것은 진짜 재미있습니다.
examples.romaji: Uri narrae saneun geoseun jinjja jaemiissthimnida.
examples.en: Living in our country is really fun.

examples.kr: 가장 중요한 것은 솔직한 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Gajang jungyohan geoseun soljikhan geosimnida.
examples.en: The most important thing is being honest.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우는 것이 어렵습니다, 그러나 계속 연습하고 싶습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul baeuneun geosi eoryeopsseumnida, geureona gyesok yeonseuphago sipseumnida.
examples.en: Learning Korean is difficult for me, but I want to keep practicing.

title: (으)ㄴ/는 것 같다 [(eu)n/neun geot gatda] (It seems like)
short_explanation: Used to express a conjecture, comparison, or resemblance; 'it seems like', 'it appears that'.
long_explanation: '(으)ㄴ/는 것 같다 [(eu)n/neun geot gatda]' is a common grammatical structure in Korean used to express a conjecture about an observed situation or to make a comparison between two things. The structure changes based on whether the preceding verb ends in a consonant (으)ㄴ 것 같다 or a vowel 는 것 같다.

examples.kr: 날씨가 춥다고 생각했는데, 바깥은 따뜻한 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chubdago saenggakhaetneunde, baggatneun ttatteuthan geot gatayo.
examples.en: I thought the weather was cold, but it seems like it's warm outside.

examples.kr: 그 여자는 아주 친절한 것 같습니다, 주변 사람들에게 항상 웃는 얼굴로 대하니까요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeojaneun aju chinjeolhan geot gatsseumnida, jubyeon saramdeulege hangsang utneun eolgullo daehanikkayo.
examples.en: That woman seems really kind, always greeting people around her with a smile.

examples.kr: 주인공이 결국엔 성공할 것 같아요, 왜냐하면 그는 어려움을 극복하는 데 굉장히 힘을 내기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: Ju-ingongi gyeolgugen seonggonghal geot gatayo, waenyahamyeon geuneun eoryeoumeul geukbokhaneun de gwaenhi himeul naegi ttaemuni-e-yo.
examples.en: I think the protagonist will succeed in the end because he puts a great deal of effort into overcoming difficulties.

examples.kr: 이번 시험은 어려울 것 같아요, 왜냐하면 이번에 배운 내용이 많이 복잡해서입니다.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeun eoryeoul geot gatayo, waenyahamyeon ibeone baewun naeyongi manhi bokjabhaeseoibnida.
examples.en: I think this test is going to be difficult, because the content we learned this time is quite complex.

title: (으)러 가다/오다 [(eu)reo gada/oda] (Go/come to do something)
short_explanation: Used to express the purpose of movement, translated as 'go/come to do something'.
long_explanation: '(으)러 가다/오다' is a conjugative expression used to indicate the intention or purpose of going somewhere or coming from somewhere to do something. In English, it translates to 'go/come to do something'. The suffix '으러' is a combination of the objective marker '(으)' and the verb '러' (to). It is used when the verb stem ends in a consonant and simply '러' is used when the verb stem ends in a vowel.
formation: Verb stem (if ends in a consonant) +으러 가다/오다 OR Verb stem (if ends in a vowel) +러 가다/오다

examples.kr: 나는 친구를 만나러 학교에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chingureul mannareo hakgyoe gaseoyo.
examples.en: I went to school to meet a friend.

examples.kr: 내일 부모님을 찾아가려고, 고향에 오려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naeil bumonim-eul chajagaryeogo, gohyang-e oreul o-ryeo-go habnida.
examples.en: I am going to my hometown to visit my parents tomorrow.

examples.kr: 그녀는 새 신발을 사러 쇼핑몰에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeo-neun sae sinbal-eul sareo syopingmole gaseyo.
examples.en: She went to the mall to buy new shoes.

examples.kr: 저는 스피치를 준비하러 도서관에 왔습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun seupichi-reul junbihareo doseogwan-e wassseubnida.
examples.en: I came to the library to prepare a speech.

title: 아/어/여도 [a/eo/yeodo] (Even if)
short_explanation: This Korean grammar point means 'Even if' and is used to indicate a situation or condition that may occur.
long_explanation: '아/어/여도 [a/eo/yeodo]' is a Korean grammar point used to express the meaning of 'Even if'. It is used when you want to indicate a hypothetical situation or condition that may occur, but you still continue conducting an action or maintain a certain state or condition irrespective of it. In essence, it is used to express a situation where the occurrence of event B does not affect event A.

examples.kr: 비가 오 아 도 학교에 가야했어요, 시험이 있기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Biga oado haggyoe gayahaesseoyo, siheomi itgi ddaemunimnida.
examples.en: Even if it rains, I have to go to school because I have a test.

examples.kr: 친구가 늦 어 도 기다리겠어요, 우리는 오랜 친구니까요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga neujeodo gidarigaesseoyo, urineun oraen chingunikka yo.
examples.en: Even if my friend is late, I will wait because we are old friends.

examples.kr: 감기가 심하 여 도 축구를 해야 해요, 팀원들에게 실망시키는 것을 원하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Gamgiga simhayeodo chukgureul haeya haeyo, timwon deurege silmang sikineun geoseul wonhaji anhayo.
examples.en: Even if I have a bad cold, I have to play football, I don't want to disappoint my teammates.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추워져 도 산책을 계속하겠어요, 그것이 스트레스를 해소하는 최고의 방법이에요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuwojyeodo sanchaeg eul gyesokhagaesseoyo, geugeosi seuteureseureul haesohaneun choegoui bangbeob ieyo.
examples.en: Even if the weather gets cold, I will continue to take a walk, as it is the best way to relieve stress.

title: 계속 [gyesok] (Continue to)
short_explanation: Used to express the continuance or repetition of an action or situation.
long_explanation: The term '계속 [gyesok]' is used in Korean language to represent the ongoing state of an event or action, similar to 'continue to' in English. It implies that an action or scenario is persisting over a period and it does not cease or take a break. It can be used with both verbs and adjectives to show that the action or condition is continuous or maintained.

examples.kr: 그는 계속 공부하고 있어서 시험을 잘 볼 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gyesok gongbuhago isseoseo siheomeul jal bol su isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: He continues to study, so I think he will do well in the test.

examples.kr: 기분이 좋아서 저는 계속 웃고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gibuni joaseo jeoneun gyesok usgo isseoyo.
examples.en: I keep laughing because I'm in a good mood.

examples.kr: 비가 계속 오고 있어서 우산을 가져가는 것이 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Biga gyesok ogo isseoseo usaneul gajyeoganeun geosi joeul geot gatayo.
examples.en: It keeps raining so it would be good to take an umbrella.

examples.kr: 그녀는 계속 건강에 신경 쓰고 있어서 병에 걸릴 확률이 적어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun gyesok geongange singyeong sseugo isseoseo byeonge geollil hwagryul-i jeogeoyo.
examples.en: She keeps caring for her health so she has less chance of getting sick.

title: 항상 [hangsang] (Always)
short_explanation: '항상 [hangsang]' is used to signify that something happens all the time or continuously.
long_explanation: '항상 [hangsang]' is an adverb used in Korean to demonstrate that an action, state or behavior is constant or continual. It is similar to the English adverb 'always'. Whether the action is in the past, present, or future, '항상' suggests it happens without any interruption.

examples.kr: 제가 항상 아침에 일찍 일어나서 학교에 먼저 도착해요.
examples.romaji: Jega hangsang achime iljjik ireonaseo hakgyoe meonjeo dochakhaeyo.
examples.en: I always wake up early in the morning and arrive at school first.

examples.kr: 우리 엄마는 항상 저녁 식사를 준비하면서 라디오를 들어요.
examples.romaji: Uri eommaneun hangsang jeonyeok siksaleul junbihamyeonseo radioleul deuleoyo.
examples.en: My mom always listens to the radio while preparing dinner.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 공부를 철저히 계획하고 그대로 따라요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang gongbuleul cheoljeohi gyehoekhago geudaero ddarayo.
examples.en: He always thoroughly plans his studies and follows it.

examples.kr: 공원에서는 항상 새가 노래를 부른다.
