examples.romaji: Gongweoneseoneun hangsang saega noraereul bureunda.
examples.en: In the park, birds are always singing.

title: (으)ㄹ 때 [(eu)l ttae] (When)
short_explanation: Used to express 'when' and connect time clauses.
long_explanation: '(으)ㄹ 때 [(eu)l ttae]' is a verb ending used in Korean to connect clauses related to time, similar to 'when' in English. It is used to express an action or state that takes place concurrently with or following the action or state of the main clause. The presence or absence of '으' is determined by the verb stem's final syllable.
formation: Verb stem + ㄹ 때 (If the verb stem ends with a vowel) / 을 때 (If the verb stem ends with a consonant)

examples.kr: 여름에는 우리집에서 바다를 볼 때, 창문을 열면 시원한 바닷바람이 들어와요.
examples.romaji: Yeoreumeneun urijibe seo bada reul bol ttae, changmuneul yeolmyeon siwonhan badabarami deureowayo.
examples.en: In the summer, when we look at the ocean from our house, if we open the window, a cool sea breeze comes in.

examples.kr: 학교를 갈 때, 버스를 타면 편해요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyo reul gal ttae, beoseu reul tamyeon pyeonhaeyo.
examples.en: When going to school, it's convenient to take the bus.

examples.kr: 숙제를 할 때, 음악을 들으면 더 집중할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sukje reul hal ttae, eumakeul deureumyeon deo jipjunghal su issseoyo.
examples.en: When doing homework, listening to music can help to concentrate better.

examples.kr: 친구를 만날 때, 함께 식사를 하면 더 즐거워요.
examples.romaji: Chingu reul mannal ttae, hamkke siksa reul hamyeon deo jeulgeowoyo.
examples.en: When meeting friends, eating together is more enjoyable.

title: 아/어/여야 되다 [a/eo/yeoya doeda] (Must, have to)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express 'must' or 'have to' and indicates something necessary to be done.
long_explanation: The '아/어/여야 되다 [a/eo/yeoya doeda]' grammar point conveys an obligation or a necessity for something to happen. It is similar to the expressions 'must' or 'have to' in English. It is used when the speaker wants to express a necessary or compulsory action that should happen in certain circumstances. It is used with action verbs.
formation: Action Verb Stems with 아/어/여 + 야 되다

examples.kr: 병원에 가려면 건강 검사를 받아야 돼요. 그래야 집에서 똑바로 공부할 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Byeongwone garyeomyeon geongang geomsa-reul bad-aya dwaeyo. Geuraeya jib-eseo ttokbaro gongbuhal su isseul geos gat-aeyo.
examples.en: You have to get a health checkup if you want to go to the hospital. Only then will I think I can study properly at home.

examples.kr: 이번 달의 매출을 증가시키기 위해선 더 많은 고객들을 끌어들여야 돼요. 그래야 월급을 받을 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon dal-ui maechul-eul jeunggasisikigi wihaeseon deo manheun gogaegdeul-eul kkeul-eodeulyeoya dwaeyo. Geuraeya wolgeub-eul bad-eul su iss-eul geoyeyo.
examples.en: To increase this month's sales, you have to attract more customers. That's the only way you can get your salary.

examples.kr: 학교에 가기 전에아침 식사를해서야 돼요. 그래야 하루 종일 에너지를 유지할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoe gagi jeoneachim sigsareul haeseoya dwaeyo. Geuraeya haru jong-il eneojireul yuji hal su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: You must have breakfast before going to school. That's the only way to maintain energy all day.

examples.kr: 나는 내일 시험이 있기 때문에오늘 밤에 공부해야 돼요. 그러지 않으면 제 시험 점수가 나빠질 거예요.
examples.romaji: Naneun naeil siheomi iss-gi ttaemuneoneul bam-e gongbuhaeya dwaeyo. Geureoji anh-eumyeon je siheom jeomsuga nappajil geoyeyo.
examples.en: I have to study tonight because I have an exam tomorrow. If not, my test scores will be bad.

title: (으)면서 [(eu)myeonseo] (While, and)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express two simultaneous actions or events.
long_explanation: The '(으)면서' [(eu)myeonseo] construction in Korean is used to show that two actions or states are taking place at the same time. It is similar to 'while' or 'and' in English. Its usage varies depending on whether the preceding verb stem ends in a vowel or a consonant. If the verb stem ends in a consonant, you add '으면서', and if it ends in a vowel simply add '면서'.
formation: 1. Verb stem ends with consonant: Verb-으면서. 2. Verb stem ends with vowel: Verb-면서

examples.kr: 나는 텔레비전을 보면서 먹었어요, 그래서 아무 말도 하지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun telebijeoneul bomyeonseo meogeosseoyo, geuraeseo amu maldo haji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: I ate while watching TV, so I didn't say anything.

examples.kr: 그녀는 버스에서 음악을 들으면서 책을 읽고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun beoseueseo eumageul deuleumyeonseo chaegilggo isseoyo.
examples.en: She is reading a book while listening to music on the bus.

examples.kr: 요즘 내 동생은 학교 공부를 하면서 일도 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum nae dongsaengeun hakgyo gongbureul hamyeonseo ildo hago isseoyo.
examples.en: These days, my younger sibling is studying and working at the same time.

examples.kr: 나는 듣기 실력을 향상하려고 팟캐스트를 들으면서 새 단어를 기록하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun deutgi sillyeogeul hyangsangharyeogo patkaeseuteureul deuleumyeonseo sae daneoreul girokago isseoyo.
examples.en: I am listening to podcasts and writing down new words to improve my listening skills.

title: 다가 [daga] (And then, but)
short_explanation: Used to show an interrupted action or an action that follows after another.
long_explanation: The postposition '다가 [daga]' in Korean language signifies an action that is happening when it gets interrupted by another action, or it describes an action that is sequentially following another action. There's a notion of causality or sequence attached to it, similar to 'and then' or 'but' in English. This grammar point vividly paints a picture of the progression or sequence of events in the sentence.

examples.kr: 저는 책을 읽다가 잠이 왔어요, 그래서 잠을 잤어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun cheageul ilgdaga jami wasseoyo, geuraeseo jameul jasseoyo.
examples.en: I was reading a book and then I felt sleepy, so I slept.

examples.kr: 식당에 가서 밥을 먹다가 친구를 만났어요.
examples.romaji: Sikdange gaseo babeul meokdaga chingureul manasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to the restaurant to eat, and then I met a friend.

examples.kr: 음악을 듣다가 갑자기 전화가 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Eumageul deudgaga gabjagi jeonhwaga wasseoyo.
examples.en: I was listening to music when suddenly the phone rang.

examples.kr: 저는 공부를 하다가 컴퓨터가 꺼져서 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gongbu hagodaga keompyuteoga ggeojyeoseo nollasseoyo.
examples.en: I was studying when the computer turned off, so I was surprised.

title: 아/어/여 보이다 [a/eo/yeo boida] (Looks, seems)
short_explanation: Used to express 'it seems', 'it looks like' or 'appears to be'.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 보이다 [a/eo/yeo boida]' is Korean grammar used to express an appearance or status of something or someone based on the observations made by the speaker. It is equivalent to 'it seems', 'it looks like', or 'appears to be' in English. It is applicable to both physical appearances and atmospheric emotions or feelings.

examples.kr: 엄마는 행복해 보이는데, 아마 좋은 소식을 들었나 봐요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun haengbokhae boineunde, ama joheun sosigeul deureotna bwayo.
examples.en: Mom looks happy, she probably heard some good news.

examples.kr: 그 사람은 늘 친절해 보이지만 실제로는 그렇지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geu sarameun neul chinjeolhae boijiman siljeoroneun geureochi anhayo.
examples.en: That person always appears to be kind, but in reality, they are not.

examples.kr: 이 방은 너무 작아 보이지만, 인테리어를 잘 하면 충분히 쓸만해요.
examples.romaji: I bangeun neomu jaga boijiman, interieoreul jal hamyeon chungbunhi sseulmanhayo.
examples.en: This room looks very small, but if you decorate it well, it's quite usable.

examples.kr: 너는 항상 바쁜 것 같아 보이는데, 어떻게 지내?
examples.romaji: Neoneun hangsang bappeun geot gata boineunde, eotteoke jinae?
examples.en: You always seem busy, how are you doing?

title: 아/어/여 버리다 [a/eo/yeo beorida] (Completely, regretfully)
short_explanation: Used to express an action is completely done or regretfully done.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 버리다 [a/eo/yeo beorida]' is a grammatical form in Korean that you use to express 1. Something is completely finished or done. 2. An action is done in a regretful way, describing a regretful or surprising situation that has already happened. It helps to express the speaker’s feelings more vividly about the situation.
formation: Verb Stem + 아/어/여 버리다. If verb stem ends with -아, -하, use -아 버리다; for -어, use -어 버리다; for -우, -으 use -여 버리다.

examples.kr: 저는 기다리다가 지쳐서 잠아버렸어요, 약속 시간에 친구를 못 만났어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gidaridaga jichyeoseo jamabeoryeosseoyo, yaksok sigane chingureul mot mannasseoyo.
examples.en: I got tired of waiting and fell asleep, so I couldn't meet my friend at the promised time.

examples.kr: 그는 스트레스를 받아서 모든 것을 잊어버렸어요, 그런데 그게 반전이었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun seuteureseureul badaseo modeun geoseul ijeobeoryeosseoyo, geureonde geuge banjeonieosseoyo.
examples.en: He was stressed out and forgot everything, but that was a twist.

examples.kr: 우리는 문제를 모두 분석해보았지만, 결국 모든 것을 포기해버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun munjeleul modu bunseokhaeboassjiman, gyeolguk modeun geoseul pogihaebeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: We analyzed all the issues, but in the end, we gave up everything.

examples.kr: 주말이 왔지만, 불행히도 저는 모든 과제를 끝내버렸어요, 그래서 쉴 시간이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jumali wassjiman, bulhaenghido jeoneun modeun gwajegeul ggeutnaebeoryeosseoyo, geuraeseo swil sigani eopseoyo.
examples.en: The weekend came, but unfortunately, I finished all my assignments, so I have no time to rest.

title: 아/어/여 놓다 [a/eo/yeo nohda] (Leave something as is)
short_explanation: Used to express the action to leave something in a specific condition or state.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 놓다 [a/eo/yeo nohda]' is a verb ending used to indicate the action of leaving something in a certain state after an action has been performed. This pattern is used when the speaker wants to describe preserving, leaving, or maintaining the status of something after an action has occurred. It emphasizes the state or condition resulting from a previous action.

examples.kr: 오늘은 집에 일찍 돌아와서 저녁 식사를 만들어 놓았어요, 저녁에 편하게 식사할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun jibe iljjik dorawaseo jeonyeok siksa-reul mandeuleo nohass-eoyo, jeonyeog-e pyeonhage siksal su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: I came home early today and made dinner, so we can easily have a meal in the evening.

examples.kr: 우리는 체크인하기 전에 호텔 방을 예약해 놓았어요, 그래서 바로 들어갈 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Ulineun chekeu-in hagi jeon-e hotel bang-eul yeyaghae nohass-eoyo, geuraeseo baro deuleogal su isseoss-eoyo.
examples.en: We had reserved the hotel room before check-in, so we could go in right away.

examples.kr: 그는 오늘 계획을 다 짜 놓고는 아무것도 하지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun oneul gyehoeg-eul da jja noko-neun amugeotdo haji anhass-eoyo.
examples.en: He made all the plans for today and then did nothing.

examples.kr: 나는 시험을 위해 모든 공부를 해 놓았지만, 시험이 취소되었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun siheom-eul wihae modeun gongbu-reul hae nohassjiman, siheom-i chwiso-doeeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: I had done all the study for the exam, but the exam was cancelled.

title: 아/어/여 지다 [a/eo/yeo jida] (Become)
short_explanation: Used to express changing state or becoming something, 'become'.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 지다 [a/eo/yeo jida]' is a verb ending used in Korean to convey the transformation, or gradually changing state, from one condition to another over a period of time. It typically has to do with changes in state, condition, emotions, inner feelings, or surrounding environment. The verb stem changes according to the final vowel.

examples.kr: 하늘이 어두워져서 길이 잘 안 보여요. 가게에 가기가 힘들겠어요.
examples.romaji: Haneuli eoduwojyeoseo giri jal an boyeoyo. Gagee gagiga himdeulgesseoyo.
examples.en: The sky became dark and the road is not visible well. It will be hard to go to the store.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추워져서 나가기가 싫어졌어요. 집에 있고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuwojyeoseo nagagiga sireojyeosseoyo. Jibe itgo sippeoyo.
examples.en: The weather became cold and I don't want to go out. I want to stay at home.

examples.kr: 오늘은 힘들었던 일이 있어서 기분이 좋아지지 않았어요. 조용히 함께 앉아 있으면 어떨까요?
examples.romaji: Oneuleun himdeureotdeon iri isseoseo gibuni joajiji anhasseoyo. Joyonghi hamkke anja isseumyeon eotteolkka yo?
examples.en: Today, because of a tough day, my mood didn't get better. How about we sit quietly together?

examples.kr: 친구가 너무 재밌게 이야기해서 기분이 좋아졌어요. 더 자주 만나야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga neomu jaemitge iyagihaseo gibuni joajyeossseoyo. Deo jaju mannayagesseoyo.
examples.en: My friend's story was so fun that I became happy. We should meet more often.

title: 아/어/여 가지다 [a/eo/yeo gajida] (Have, possess)
short_explanation: This is used when describing oneself or others having or possessing certain qualities, appearances, or characteristics.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 가지다 [a/eo/yeo gajida]' implies 'having' or 'possessing' certain qualities, traits, characteristics, or appearances. It is often used when the speaker wants to express someone's possessing certain aspects confidently or conclusively. This formation is used to express a static state, rather than an action or event. It can also be used when affirming the existence of certain tangible or intangible things and is often used with adjectives.

examples.kr: 그녀는 아름다운 눈을 가지고 있어요, 마치 밤하늘에 빛나는 별처럼 반짝여요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun areumdaun nuneul gajigo isseoyo, machi bamhaneure bitnaneun byeolcheoreom banjjagyeoyo.
examples.en: She has beautiful eyes that sparkle like stars in the night sky.

examples.kr: 저는 좋은 친구를 많이 가지고 있어요, 그래서 항상 외롭지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun joeun chingureul mani gajigo isseoyo, geuraeseo hangsang oeropji anhayo.
examples.en: I have many good friends, so I am never lonely.

examples.kr: 우리 회사는 강력한 경쟁력을 가지고 있어야해요, 그래야 성장할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Uri hoesaneun gangryeokhan gyeongjaengryeogeul gajigo isseoyahaeyo, geuraeya seongjanghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Our company needs to have strong competitiveness, otherwise we won't be able to grow.

examples.kr: 그는 뛰어난 능력을 가지고 있어서 어떤 일이든지 해낼 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun ttwieonan neungryeogeul gajigo isseoseo eotteon irideunji haenael su isseoyo.
examples.en: He has outstanding ability, so he can do anything.

title: (으)ㄴ/는 편이다 [(eu)n/neun pyeonida] (Tend to)
short_explanation: Used to express someone’s tendency, habit or characteristic.
long_explanation: The phrase '(으)ㄴ/는 편이다 [(eu)n/neun pyeonida]' is used in Korean to indicate a tendency, habit, or characteristic that someone frequently exhibits. This construction can be used to refer to behaviors, preferences, or characteristics that are habitual or typical for someone. It is used with action and descriptive verbs, after which either '는 편이다' or 'ㄴ 편이다' is added depending on whether the final syllable of the verb stem ends with a vowel or a consonant.
formation: Descriptive verb + 는 편이다 / Action verb + ㄴ 편이다

examples.kr: 그는 일찍 일어나는 편이에요, 주말에도 항상 아침 일찍 일어나요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun iljjik ireonaneun pyeonieyo, jumalgdo hangsang achim iljjik ireonayo.
examples.en: He tends to wake up early, he always wakes up early in the morning even on weekends.

examples.kr: 저는 매운 음식을 잘 먹는 편이에요, 캡사이신이 많이 들어간 음식을 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ma-eun eumsigeul jal meogneun pyeonieyo, kaepsaisini manhige deureogan eumsigeul johahaeyo.
examples.en: I tend to eat spicy food well, I like food with a lot of capsaicin.

examples.kr: 우리 동생은 안전을 중시하는 편이에요, 그래서 항상 안전벨트를 착용해요.
examples.romaji: Uri dongsaengeun anjeoneul jungsihaneun pyeonieyo, geuraeseo hangsang anjeonbelteureul chak-yonghaeyo.
examples.en: My younger sibling tends to prioritize safety, so he always wears a seatbelt.

examples.kr: 나는 책을 읽는 편이에요, 특히 공상 과학 소설을 많이 읽어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chaekeul ilkneun pyeonieyo, teukhi gongsang gwahak suseoreul manhi ilkeoyo.
examples.en: I tend to read books, especially science fiction novels.

title: 는/은 데 [neun/eun de] (Situation or condition)
short_explanation: Used to describe a situation or condition, often when the speaker is about to say something about the situation.
long_explanation: '는/은 데 [neun/eun de]' is a conjunction used in Korean grammar, often in a situation where the speaker explains a condition or context, and then adds new, often unexpected or contrasted information related to that condition. It's often used as a transition between two clauses, connecting the prior situation with the additional information.
formation: Noun/Adjective/Verb + 는/은 데 + rest of the sentence

examples.kr: 아직 학생인데 돈을 벌려고 아르바이트를 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ajik haksanginde don-eul beollyeogo aleubaiteuleul hago iss-eoyo.
examples.en: I'm still a student, and I'm working part-time to earn money.

examples.kr: 어제 내가 집에 왔는데 아무도 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje naega jibe watneunde amudo eobseosseoyo.
examples.en: I came home yesterday, but there was no one there.

examples.kr: 지금 비가 오는데 우산을 가져오지 않아서 문제예요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum biga oneunde usaneul gajyeooji anhaseo munjeyeoyo.
examples.en: It's raining now, but I didn't bring an umbrella, which is a problem.

examples.kr: 저는 사람들과 얘기하는 것을 좋아하는데 부끄러움이 많아서 어렵습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun saramdeulgwa yaegihaneun geoseul joahaneunde bukkeureoumi manaseo eoryeopseumnida.
examples.en: I like talking to people, but it's difficult because I'm very shy.

title: 아/어/여야겠다 [a/eo/yeoya getda] (Should, must)
short_explanation: This pattern expresses assumption or necessity, a determination, or conclusion that one 'should' or 'must' do something.
long_explanation: '아/어/여야겠다 [a/eo/yeoya getda]' is a Korean grammar point used to convey necessity or assumption. It can be translated as 'should' or 'must' in English. It is used when the speaker concludes that a particular action must be taken or a situation is believed to be a certain way based on certain circumstances, events or judgments. It is often used when sharing personal opinions, making judgments, or suggesting what needs to be done.

examples.kr: 이 레포트를 빨리 완성해야겠어요, 제출기한이 내일이니까요.
examples.romaji: I lepoteureul bballyi wanseonghaeyagetseoyo, jesulgihan-i nae-il-ikka-yo.
examples.en: I should finish this report quickly, because the submission deadline is tomorrow.

examples.kr: 우리는 시간이 없으니까 택시를 타야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun sigani eops-eunikka taeksireul t-ayagetseoyo.
examples.en: We should take a taxi since we don't have time.

examples.kr: 이 음식이 맛있어 보이니까, 나도 한 번 먹어봐야겠다.
examples.romaji: I eumsigi mas-iss-e boinikka, nado han beon meog-eo bwayagetda.
examples.en: This food looks delicious, I should try it as well.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추워서 더 따뜻한 옷을 입어야겠다.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuwoseo deo ttatteuthan os-eul ib-eoyagetda.
examples.en: The weather is cold, so I should wear warmer clothes.

title: 아/어/여서는 안 되다 [a/eo/yeoseoneun an doeda] (Must not, shouldn't)
short_explanation: Used to express prohibition; 'must not', 'shouldn't'.
long_explanation: The '아/어/여서는 안 되다 [a/eo/yeoseoneun an doeda]' grammar point is used in Korean to express a prohibition or restriction, translating to 'must not' or 'shouldn't' in English. It indicates that the action denoted by the verb in the sentence is not permissible. It is widely used to make negative commands and establish rules or guidelines.

examples.kr: 이 병원에서는 담배를 피우어서는 안 됩니다, 건강에 해로운 행동입니다.
examples.romaji: I byeongwoneseoneun dambaereul piueoseoneun an doemnida, geongange haeroun haengdongimnida.
examples.en: In this hospital, you must not smoke, it's harmful to health.

examples.kr: 비밀인 사실을 남에게 말해서는 안 됩니다, 그것은 신뢰를 잃게 합니다.
examples.romaji: Bimilin sasileul namege malhaseoneun an doemnida, geugeoseun sinloereul ilhge haneun ilimnida.
examples.en: You must not tell a secret fact to others, it can result in losing trust.

examples.kr: 시험 중에는 친구와 대화해서는 안 됩니다, 그것은 불공정한 행동으로 간주됩니다.
examples.romaji: siheom jungeun chinguwa daehwahaseoneun an doemnida, geogeoseun bulgongjeonghan haengdongeuro ganjudoebnida.
examples.en: You must not talk with friends during an exam, it is considered unfair behavior.

examples.kr: 나는 숙제를 빨리 해서는 안 됩니다, 문제를 이해하지 못하면 반드시 선생님에게 질문해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun sukjereul ppalli haeoseoneun an doemnida, munjeleul ihaehaji mothamyeon bandeusi seonsaengnimege jilmunhaeya hamnida.
examples.en: I must not do my homework quickly; if I do not understand the problem, I must ask the teacher.

title: 아/어/여 주세요 [a/eo/yeo juseyo] (Please give/do for me)
short_explanation: It is used when asking someone politely to do something for you.
long_explanation: The '아/어/여 주세요 [a/eo/yeo juseyo]' grammar form in Korean is generally used when you want to request someone to do something for you in a polite and respectful manner. It is attached to the stem of action verbs and can be used in various contexts where a respectful request or command is required.

examples.kr: 같이 머물 수 있는 곳을 찾아 주세요, 제 친구와 함께 한국을 여행하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Gachi meomul su issneun goseul chaja juseyo, je chin-guwa hamkke hanguk-eul yeohaenghago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: Please find a place where we can stay together, I want to travel to Korea with my friend.

examples.kr: 이 문장에서 틀린 부분을 찾아 주세요, 제가 몰라서 도움이 필요해요.
examples.romaji: I munjangeseo teullin buneul chaja juseyo, jegamollaseo doumi pilyohaeyo.
examples.en: Please find the wrong part in this sentence, I need help because I don't know.

examples.kr: 집에 가는 길에 우유를 사와 주세요, 집에 우유가 부족해서요.
examples.romaji: Jib-e ganeun gil-e uyu-leul sawa juseyo, jib-e uyuga bujokhaeseoyo.
examples.en: Please buy milk on your way home, because we are short of milk at home.

examples.kr: 이 메일에 답장을 보내 주세요, 곧 답변이 필요해요.
examples.romaji: I meir-e dabjang-eul bonae juseyo, got dabbyeon-i pilyohaeyo.
examples.en: Please send a reply to this email, I need a response soon.

title: 아/어/여 드리다 [a/eo/yeo deurida] (To give – honorific)
short_explanation: Used to convey politeness when an action is done for someone; the honorific form of 'giving'.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 드리다 [a/eo/yeo deurida]' is an honorific grammar point used in Korean to show respect when giving or doing something for someone. It is more polite than the standard verb '아/어/여 주다 [a/eo/yeo juda]' for 'to give'. Korean language places high emphasis on social ranking and relationship, and using the appropriate level of formality and politeness in verbs contributes significantly to this aspect of the culture.

examples.kr: 알려드리기 위해 제 전화 번호를 당신에게 드립니다.
examples.romaji: Allyeodeurigi wihae je jeonhwa beonhoreul dangsinege deurimnida.
examples.en: I give you my phone number to inform you.

examples.kr: 고객님께 더 좋은 서비스를 제공드리고자 항상 노력하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Gogaegnimkke deo joheun seobiseureul jegongdeurigoja hangsang noryeokhago issseubnida.
examples.en: We are always striving to provide better service to our valued customers.

examples.kr: 어머니께 편지를 써드렸습니다.
examples.romaji: Eomeonikke pyeonjireul sseodeuryeossseubnida.
examples.en: I wrote a letter for my mother.

examples.kr: 학생들에게 좋은 지식을 가르치지 않아드릴 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeurege joheun jisigeul gaerchiji anadeuril su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I cannot fail to impart good knowledge to my students.

title: 다니다 [danida] (To attend, go regularly)
short_explanation: Used to express the idea of 'attending' or 'going regularly'.
long_explanation: '다니다 [danida]' is a verb used in Korean to indicate a repeated and continuous action of going somewhere or doing something. It conveys a sense of habit or a regular routine, akin to 'attend' or 'go regularly' in English. It is used to emphasize the continuity or the regularity of an action and is often used in sentences to express an ongoing activity or habitual action.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침 일찍 운동하러 체육관에 다니다가 습관이 되었어요, 그래서 체력이 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achim iljjik undonghareo cheyukgane danidaga seubgwani doeeosseoyo, geureoseo cheryeogi joeajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I got into the habit of going to the gym early every morning for exercise, so my stamina improved.

examples.kr: 수업을 듣기 위해 학생들은 매일 학교에 다녀야 합니다, 그래야 공부를 잘 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sueobeul deutgi wihae haksaengdeureun maeil hakgyoe danyaeya hamnida, geuraeya gongbureul jal hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Students need to attend school every day in order to take classes, only then can they study well.

examples.kr: 나는 친구들과 주말에 카페에 다니며 시간을 보냈어요, 그래서 소중한 추억들이 많아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chingudeulgwa jumale kapee danimyeo siganeul bonaesseoyo, geureoseo sojunghan chueokdeuri manhajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I spent time going to cafes with my friends on weekends, so I have many precious memories.

examples.kr: 이 회사에서 일하기 위해서는 매일 사무실에 다녀야 해요, 그래야 사무실 일을 처리할 수 있으니까요.
examples.romaji: I hoesaeseo ilhagiwihaneneun maeil samusile danyaeya haeyo, geuraeya samusil ireul cheorihal su issnikkayo.
examples.en: To work at this company you need to go to the office every day, as that's where you can handle office work.

title: 아/어/여 가다 [a/eo/yeo gada] (Be going to do)
short_explanation: It is used to express the speaker’s intention to do something or make plans for the future.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 가다 [a/eo/yeo gada]' is a grammatical form in Korean often used to show an intention or a plan to do something in the future. It contains the atmosphere of 'I'm going to' in English. It is used when the speaker clearly has a plan or intention for a future action.

examples.kr: 저는 이번 주말에 영화를 보러 가려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ibeon jumare yeonghwareul boreo garyeogo haeyo.
examples.en: I am planning to go see a movie this weekend.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 부터 공부하러 도서관에 가려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil buteo gongbuhareo doseogwane garyeogo hamnida.
examples.en: We are planning to go to the library to study from tomorrow.

examples.kr: 그녀는 이번 주에 친구들과 여행가려고 계획하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun ibeon jue chingudeulgwa yeohaenggareyogo gyehoekago isseoyo.
examples.en: She is planning to go on a trip with her friends this week.

examples.kr: 너무 배고파서 점심 먹으러 식당에 가려고 하거든요.
examples.romaji: Neomu baegopaseo jeomsim meogreuro sikdange garyeogo ha-geodeunyo.
examples.en: I'm so hungry that I'm going to go to the restaurant to eat lunch.

title: 아/어/여 오다 [a/eo/yeo oda] (Come to do)
short_explanation: This pattern is used to convey the meaning 'come to do', 'end up doing', or 'eventually do'.
long_explanation: It is a structure used in Korean language to express the progression of an action, translated as 'come to (do something)', 'end up (doing something)', or 'eventually (do something)'. It implies that the speaker didn’t intend to do the action or it was unexpected to them. This grammar form is usually used with action verbs.
formation: Verb stem + 아/어/여 오다 (If the verb stem’s last syllable has a final consonant, use '아 오다', if it ends in 'ㅏ' or 'ㅗ', use '아 오다', but in any other cases, use '어 오다')

examples.kr: 그 여우는 손바닥 위에 닭을 볼 수 있기 때문에 먹으러 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeouneun sonbadak wie dalkeul bol su itgi ttaemune meogeureo wasseoyo.
examples.en: That fox came to eat because it could see the chicken on the palm.

examples.kr: 방학이 되니까 친구들과 함께 여행가려고 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Banghagi doinikka chingudeulgwa hamkke yeohaenggareyogo wasseoyo.
examples.en: Since it's the holidays, I came to travel with my friends.

examples.kr: 다이어트를 시작하려고 일찍 집에서 나와 운동하러 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Daieoteureul sijakharyeogo iljjik jibeseo nawa undonghareo wasseoyo.
examples.en: I left the house early and came to exercise to start a diet.

examples.kr: 너무 많이 먹었기 때문에 걷기 시작해서 집에 도착하다시피 했어요.
examples.romaji: Neomu mani meogeotgi ttaemune geotgi sijakhaeseo jibe dochakhadasihaesseoyo.
examples.en: I ate so much that I started walking and almost arrived home.

title: 아/어/여 있다 [a/eo/yeo itda] (To be doing)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to describe an ongoing state or activity.
long_explanation: 아/어/여 있다 is a Korean grammatical expression used to indicate a continuous or ongoing action or status. The verb stem changes according to the vowel in its final syllable. If the vowel is 아 or 오, we use 아 있다. If the final vowel is any vowel other than 아 or 오, we use 어 있다. And if the verb stem ends in 하다, we use 여 있다. The tense of the sentence can be present, past or future depending on the use of 있다 or 없다.

examples.kr: 나는 지금 책을 읽고 있어요, 그래서 나중에 스터디 그룹에 참가하려고 준비하고 있답니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun jigeum chaegeul ilgo isseoyo, geuraeseo najunge seuteodi geurupe chamgaharyeogo junbihago itseumnida.
examples.en: I am reading a book right now, so I am preparing to participate in a study group later.

examples.kr: 엄마는 요리하고 있어요, 그러니깐 나는 방에 있어서 도와줄 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun yorihago isseoyo, geureonikkan naneun bange isseoseo dowajul su eopseoyo.
examples.en: My mom is cooking, so I am in the room and can't help her.

examples.kr: 오빠는 혼자서 연습하고 있어요, 그래서 나는 그를 방해하지 않으려고 느린 음악을 듣고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Oppaneun honjaseo yeonseubhago isseoyo, geuraeseo naneun geureul banghaehaji anhuryeogo neurin eumageul deudgo isseoyo.
examples.en: My brother is practicing alone, so I am listening to slow music to not bother him.

examples.kr: 친구들은 축구를 하고 있어요, 그런데 비가 오기 시작하니까 그들은 이제 그만두려고 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeureun chukgureul hago isseoyo, geureonde biga ogi sijakhanikka geudeureun ije geumanduryeogo hago isseoyo.
examples.en: My friends are playing soccer, but since it started to rain, they are about to stop now.

title: 아/어/여 보다 [a/eo/yeo boda] (Try to do)
short_explanation: Used to express an attempt or trial to do something.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 보다 [a/eo/yeo boda]' is a Korean grammar point used to express the meaning of trying something or making an attempt to do something. This form is used to indicate that the speaker is going to try and do something to see what will happen, or in other words, to test out a certain action or situation. It indicates a sense of experimentation or trial-and-error.

examples.kr: 새로운 요리법을 배웠기 때문에, 오늘 저녁 식사를 해 보려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Saeroun yoribeobeul baewotgi ttaemune, oneul jeonyeok siksa-reul hae boryeogo habnida.
examples.en: Since I learned new cooking methods, I will try to make dinner tonight.

examples.kr: 영어를 배우는 것이 어렵지만, 계속 공부해 보려고합니.
examples.romaji: Yeongeoreul ba-u-neun geosi eoryeop-jiman, gyesok gongbuhae boryeogohabni.
examples.en: Learning English is difficult, but I will try to keep studying.

examples.kr: 아이들에게 어렵지 않을지 모르겠지만, 로봇 공학을 가르쳐 보겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Aideurege eoryeopji anheulji moreugessjiman, robot gonghageul gareuchyeo bogessseubnida.
examples.en: I am not sure if it will be difficult for children, but I will try to teach robotics.

examples.kr: 이 가방이 맞는지 확인하려면, 실제로 집에 가져가 보아야합니다.
examples.romaji: I gabangi matneunji hwaginharyeomyeon, siljero jibe gajyeoga boayahabnida.
examples.en: In order to confirm if this bag is right, I have to actually try bringing it home.
